B000BW7QWW|5.0|Joss Whedon's space western didn't find a wide audience on televison and was unceremoniously yanked from Fox's lineup despite rock solid writing.  Given the choice to make money or make quality programs, broadcasters logically chose the former.  Fortunately, the story didn't end there for the nomad ship, the Serenity.  The crew and the beloved bucket of bolts they call home, return on the big screen this time.  Malcom Reynolds [Nathan Filton] and his ragtam team of space buccaneers are harboring a pint size weapon in the form of a girl named River [Summer Glau].  She has used her mind reading abilities to inadvertantly garner some secrets that the evil Alliance doesn't want found out.  This leads to deadly entanglements with the Alliance, space cannibals called Reavers and a forgotten planet named Miranda.  Serenity's staff soon learns that the 90 pound waif that has been riding around with them is capable of taking on whole groups of weapon toting henchman by herself without breaking a nail.  You don't need to be a fan of the television series to enjoy this science fiction saga [as of this writing I have yet to see any of the 14 episodes].  The characters are well drawn out and the plot isn't so terribly complicated that you can't figure out the basic details quick enough to keep up with the fast moving script.  The movie has a silly, spaghetti western feel to it that somehow comes across as charming and amusing rather than quirky and annoying.  Comparisons to the Star Wars universe are inevitable, but Serenity doesn't get swallowed up by expectations of grandeur and legacy.  It is free to be razor sharp, witty and simply enjoyable.  At times, the George Lucas films seem to take themselves a little too seriously.  That is never a problem with Serenity.  Joss Whedon manages a near perfect balance between serious action sequences and humor.

B0000TB01Y|5.0|The \\"Wicked\\" Original Broadway Cast recording sparkles with energy and emotion, and features the original performers for whom the music was specifically written.  The musical version of \\"Wicked\\" differs substantially from the original novel by Gregory Maguire but the altered storyline, in which the minor character of Glinda the Good in the novel is elevated to co-star status in the musical, becomes a story of the friendship between two young women and the sacrifices they must make to be true to their ideals.   <br /> <br />While this makes the musical story completely different than the book it is arguably more compelling than the actual novel, as evidenced by the show's runaway success on Broadway, Chicago and on national tour.  Add composer Stephen Schwartz's best work since \\"Pippen\\" 30 years ago and the result is a show that IMO is easily as enjoyable as \\"Les Miserables\\" and far more gripping than \\"Phantom of the Opera\\" or \\"Miss Saigon.\\"   <br /> <br />Schwartz introduces the dramatic \\"Wicked Witch\\" theme (a six chord progression whose unspoken lyrics purportedly are \\"oh no, the witch is here\\") in the first moments of the overture and recalls it chillingly again moments later when it becomes apparent at the Wicked Witch's birth that something is horribly wrong.  Then, when the young Witch is finally united with her true love in the second act, the love theme utilizes the exact same chord progression, but now set in a compelling ostinato figure that underscores the urgency and desperation of their fleeting moment together.  The Hindemith-like antiphony of \\"No One Mourns the Wicked\\" both jars us and serves to clue us into realizing that something's not quite right during the \\"Ding-Dong the Witch is Dead\\"-like opening celebration number. <br /> <br />The hopeful yet tragic \\"Unlimited\\" theme arcs through the story and is a clever homage to the \\"Wizard of Oz\\" movie score, using the same first seven notes as \\"Somewhere Over the Rainbow\\" and then diverging.  Schwartz noted in interviews that he chose to use only the first seven notes as an inside joke because copyright laws specifically define eight notes as the point where infringement on someone else's tune occurs.   <br /> <br />The music of \\"Wicked\\" is for the most part completely dependent on the context of the musical and the individual numbers do not stand alone well, but Ms. Chenowith's \\"Popular\\" and Ms. Menzel's legitimate showstopper \\"Defying Gravity\\" are justifiably acclaimed, and the de facto finale \\"For Good\\" is already available on Amazon on two other non-Broadway recordings, one of which features the composer singing half of the duet himself.   <br /> <br />The aforementioned love song \\"As Long as You're Mine\\" also has to be heard in the context of the story to be fully appreciated; the audience at this point in the musical has been taken on a journey from the apparent celebration of the witch's demise at the beginning to the show 180 degrees to where we now understand her character and motivations to where from \\"Defying Gravity\\" onwards we are actually cheering for the witch to succeed; by the time this duet comes along near the end of the second act, the witch and her true love are being hunted across the land and we already know that our heroine is doomed to melt (and soon!) at the hands of a certain Kansas farmgirl, lending the lyrics and chord progressions, maudlin at best out of context, tremendous pathos and power akin to \\"The Fall of Saigon\\" and \\"The Last Night of the World\\" in \\"Miss Saigon.\\"  Only when you see the musical do you understand why Schwartz chose Fiyero's otherwise jarring verse \\"Maybe I'm brainless, maybe I'm wise.\\" <br /> <br />\\"Wicked\\" is well worth your time but you'll enjoy it infinitely more once you also see the show, and the show itself is well worth a weekend trip to the nearest city staging a production to see it.

B00005NC66|5.0|First, I must say I enjoy these types of movies.  Characters who are living on the edge of society, almost oblivious to it.  That obviously says something about me, the viewer, the interpreter.  It also says something about how I view reality.  As Marx noted, humans are self-interested creatures at the core.  The rest is constructed fluff.  This movie, for me, flows along that premise.  Second, I had read nothing on this film until after I saw it a couple days ago.  I knew Jean-Luc Godard was a very influential filmmaker, but little about this film itself.  When I first saw the jump cuts I thought, \\"what the h&*@?\\"  Others say those were political comments, revolutionary, forced, or just plain amateurish.  What Roger Ebert conveys is Godard had to cut 30 minutes of film, so he went through and cut out anything he found boring.  Sounds logical.  This led to the final product, which includes the jump cuts.  Well, I think as a style it ends up working.  This is a \\"rough\\" film about an \\"amateur\\" criminal.  Perhaps along its core is a universal political statement about social authority and the individual reactions to it.  In the movie people die, and they die through the unpolished style of the main character, who simply lives how he chooses.    Third, to me, the camera work, the acting, the script, all flow seemingly into a very stylized film that pays homage to the petty crime drama genre.  In a way it is Reservoir Dogs before Reservoir Dogs.  But it is also more.  It tells the truth about love.  Love isn't as simple as meeting somebody, sleeping with them, marrying them, having children, aging, and dying.  Love, like life, is beautiful but messy.  This film matches love and life perfectly.  Just as amazingly, like the other film I mentioned, it manages to remain \\"on the fringe\\" of cinema while reinventing the industry in an important way and becoming a topic in mainstream discussions about film making.  Certainly we have moved on.  Breathless is not the only great movie ever made.  There are movies made today that may even be its equal.  Breathless becomes immortal, then dies.

B000BJS4SU|4.0|Kudos to John Mayer... instead of churning out another pop album (which would probably give him another Grammy nod), he does what he wants to do, aligning himself with two of the best in the business (Steve Jordan and Pino Palladino).   <br /> <br />John shows us nuances of what he can do on guitar... but I can't say there's ever a track where he \\"lets it all go.\\"  A few times while I was listening to the album, I felt that the song deserved a little more \\"tasty\\" solo than the one that John chose for the particular song.  Nevertheless, he sings and plays with a lot of emotion... emotion which isn't depicted as well because of the recording quality, but I will get to that in a minute.  John seems like he is really enjoying himself on stage.  I applaud his choice to avoid many of his hits, instead focusing on the trio's original songs, cover tunes, and some other songs he has written.  His version of \\"Something's Missing\\" is extremely good, particularly with Jordan and Palladino's excellent playing on it.  As for \\"Daughters,\\" it just didn't fit; it seems like it was just thrown in as a chance for the 15-year-old girls to scream. <br /> <br />Now for the recording quality... it seems as if no editing or mixing was done whatsoever.  It seems as if my buddy went down to the club, recorded the band with a tape recorder, and burned me a copy.  I suppose the band was trying for the ultimate \\"live\\" album; the cd liner basically brags about its \\"raw\\" nature.  The quality takes away from the album, to say the least. <br /> <br />This isn't your kid sister's Mayer album... this shows a little of what Mayer can do.  It's obvious that Mayer has recently been reinventing himself as a Rock/Blues player who also sings, rather than a singer who just so happens to be a wonderful guitarist.  I'd love to hear a studio effort from these guys... I think we haven't even seen the best of John Mayer yet.

B0001OOUEM|5.0|In this brilliant, poignant novel, Michael Cunningham captures the lives of three remarkable women going about an ordinary day, much as Virginia Woolf did in \\"Mrs. Dalloway.\\" In the first section, Woolf is planning the aforementioned novel and dealing with an impendinig migraine, that often brings suicidal thoughts, as well. In the second, Clarissa, a housewife, is planning a party for her poet friend who has AIDS, Richard, with her partner Sally. In the third, Laura Brown, also a housewife in the Forties, and mother of Richard is planning a party for her husband, but resents the time it take away from reading her her novel \\"Mrs. Dalloway.\\" With evocative prose, the author goes inside each woman's mind, and the results are unforgettable. <br />

B000AP04FG|3.0|I avoided this movie in theatres because of all the Brad Pitt/Angelina Jollie tabloid crap.  I saw them on five different magazines every day, and every week a new one with similar picture on each cover, so I had no desire to shell out 9 bucks to see them smirk at one another for two hours.  These are two \\"actors\\" I never much respected anyway.   <br /> <br />Plus the movie looked really dumb.   <br /> <br />But removed from all that sickness, after checking it out at home a few months later, I would never call it a great movie and technically, yep, its pretty dumb, but it has moments and I have to admit the stars are likeable in spite of their constant public over-saturation.   <br /> <br />He's a spy/killer, she's a spy/killer, and they are married, but he doesn't know what she does and she doesn't know what he does (riiiiight), but 5 years into their marriage, one day they put two and two together (the same day, at the same time.... after 5 years - again, riiiiight) and on this day so do the different contacting agencies they work for.  So now they have to kill each other, or get taken out by their respective employers.  <br /> <br />(It took the geniuses in intelligence at those firms five years to figure out they were married?  You'd think you'd know all there is to know about your super-spy employees before you entrust them with government secrets or worse; and what's with them all suddenly getting a clue at the same time?)   <br /> <br />At first they are content to kill each other (each had been treating the marriage as a cover story so no real feeling should exist) and this results in some humorous banter and husband on wife and vise-versa beatings (if that's your bag), but wouldn't ya know they actually do love each other (an epiphany that is awakened after beating the crap out of each other turns them on so much that they stop fighting long enough to screw on shards of broken glass) and soon it's them against their agencies.   <br /> <br />SPOILER ALERT!!!!!!! <br /> <br />But true to form those geniuses are pretty easy to beat.  At least that's what the abrupt ending that doesn't explain anything leads us to believe.  So they wiped out the baddies that were after them that night.  Wouldn't they send more the next day?  In the last scene the couple says all is well and they redid the house they blew to sh*t earlier.  So they are living in the same place?  Why wouldn't someone just blow there house up again?   <br /> <br />I'll do it!   <br /> <br />So, yeah, it's that kind of movie.  But I did smile a lot.  The premise, dumb, no scratch that, absolutely impossible as it - I mean this isn't like, 'oh, he couldn't get shot that many times and survive,' or 'he wouldn't survive that fall' - I mean none of this would ever, ever happen - still makes way for lots of clever gags.  Imagine if your significant other was this person and so were you.  The movie plays that to the hilt and is better for it.  If you're going to stray this far from reality and still expect us to care about the characters then you better go for broke and make sure you play every other angle and possibility up as much as you can.  For the most part, this movie takes full advantage.  I liked how they both had guns and bombs hidden all over the house, in places the other doesn't go and when they are fighting against one another, I liked their banter and the way they knew how to get to one another, whether it be because of their training or because they are husband and wife; often the two reasons are one in the same.  And when they join forces there is the predictable power struggle.  There is a scene where they compare body counts the way couples compare their number of sex partners.  And the scenes with their shrink that bookend the film and set the jokey tone are funny.   <br /> <br />Most importantly and most surprisingly the two leads are solid and likeable and that goes a long way in a dumb movie like this.  If we can't buy them and we sure as hell can't buy this premise, then we can't by the movie.  Their characters are a little clichd and under-developed.  She is the by-the-book, team player who is good at throwing knives, while He is the somewhat goofy frat-guy who, judging by the evidence submitted, enjoys kicking people and hitting them with objects he finds around the room.  Hey, one more caricature and they'd be Charlie's Angels!   <br /> <br />There is Vince Vaughn, but he is underused and doesn't appear much in a kick-ass mood.   <br /> <br />Though the movie explores and exploits most of the possible fun scenarios to come out of a situation like this, I would argue the action sequences come up far shorter.  There are really only three, one is a car chase that is not staged with any real zest or originality and is completely sunk by the two leads' constant sarcastic addressing of each other as \\"dear,\\" or \\"honey\\" before giving an instruction or ribbing one another.  We get it, you're a married couple and you are shooting at people!  Shut up and shoot!   <br /> <br />Blame the director.  I know the guy did \\"The Bourne Identity,\\" and that was generaly well-received, but here he has no style and his attempts at it range from shaky camera work when it is not needed (like early scenes with Brangelina in a hotel room) to slow-mo editing and camera twirls as in the generic shoot-out finale.  All the actions scenes are pretty generic.  The car chase I mentioned pales in comparison to not only great film chase sequences, but doesn't have the excitment and inovativeness, or the hard edge of, say freeway chase in \\"Lethal Weapon 4\\" or even the hot, flashy cars and big pile-ups of crash-wizard Michael Bay's \\"Bad Boys II\\" (or any of his films for that matter).  There is just nothing special, unique or exciting going for any of the action in this movie.  It's a shame it didn't try harder.  Those two titles (and many others) are proof you can be a \\"dumb action comedy\\" and still blow audiences away.  <br /> <br />Sozero logic and poor direction sink its chances of being much more than a guilty pleasure.  But thanks to the charismatic leads and some clever bafoonery, it is a pleasure all the same.

Pretty darn good. <br /> <br />Opening with the soaring \\"I'm Outta Love\\", the tracks the precede in the order they were released.  Most the material off the \\"Not that Kind\\" and \\"Freak Of Nature\\" is typical girl with big voice material. And what about these new songs?  \\"In Your Eyes\\" is a competent rock ballad, but hold on to your seats for the collection's true gem, \\"Pieces Of A Dream\\". But ulitmately this is a singles release and present the artist's best known tracks. <br /> <br />The \\"special edition\\" comes with a bonus remix disc featuring a collection ofdance mixes.  It's truly genuis idea that is a welcome choice from the ever popular additional DVD that is popping up everywhere.  Most of the tracks have had releases elsewhere, but for US fans it's a great chance to get them all in one spot without have to search.  Some tunes are repeated and having rarities (b-sides and rare mixes) would have made this disc truly amazing. <br /> <br />The packaging also deserves a nod.  The designers really rocked out and made this release memorable.  The CD's are house inside the inner sleeves or a little hardcover book (the album cover is still intact and looks breathtaking).  The pages of the book feature the photos apparently taken for the since cancelled US release of \\"Anastacia\\" and re-shot \\"Left Outside Alone\\" video.  The full lyrics and credits are included on the high glass, glossy stock paper.  The CD's are a bit hard to get out of the sleeve and can become scratched easily if not handled with a little TLC.  So be careful with this one!!  <br /> <br />The final product is a great one.  Anastacia is an amazing singer/songwriter with a great collection of hits to draw from.  In the season of \\"best of/greatest hits\\" collections this one is stand out above the rest.

But that doesn't matter because in the end this is a fun, scary, clever film that deserves to be seen. <br /> <br />The premise of a man who can see and interact with spirits has been done before.  So what makes this film so unique?  To begin with, the writing.  Ghosts are handled so matter of factly that we are immediately immersed in this strange story of Frank Bannister and the evil Shadow of Death that stalks his hometown.  How do you stop a spirit that you can see but not really touch?  How do you keep it from killing people right in front of you?  That's what Frank has to figure out. <br /> <br />The special effects are amazing.  Death himself is a creepy, flowing predator. You never know what's going to happen next, but it never seems forced or difficult to follow. <br /> <br />Overall, this is a great film that just gets better with age.  See it.
B0000C0FJB|5.0|In combination with the release of their double-DVD Rush in Rio, which documents the final concert of their 2002 Vapor Trails tour, Rush also released a Rush in Rio triple CD as an audio supplement to the DVD visuals. Or, as percussionist Neil Peart so eloquently stated, \\"...for some people (that) might prefer to listen to us without having to look at us...\\"  <br /> <br />Well, after witnessing the DVD video on the big screen and having seen Rush live twice on their latest, and hopefully not final tour, I was really anxious to take in all the nuances of the triple-live CD.  <br /> <br />Now I, like many other Rush fans, were a little surprised that the boys from the great white north were putting out another live album so soon after the last one. In fact, in their 30 year career, Rush followed the pattern of releasing four studio albums, then one live album. That pattern held true up until Rush in Rio which followed after only one studio album since their last live effort, 'Different Stages'. Regardless of this blip in their pattern, Rush in Rio is a very welcomed addition to an ever-growing and magnificent collection of work by these often misunderstood, grossly unappreciated and underrated masterful musicians. Man, say that fast five times! :-)  <br /> <br />Another distinction between this live CD and others released by Rush in the past is the fact that all of the performances, save for two 'bonus' tracks, were all recorded from the single show held in Rio de Janeiro at a stadium packed with 40,000 amazing Brazilian fans. Previous live CDs understandably took the best performances from a variety of venues and dates, all combined to treat the listener to the very best of Rush live.  <br /> <br />However the fact that the entire CD was recorded from a single show makes little difference as the Gods were clearly looking down on Rush that one magical evening in Brazil. Rush, without question, produced arguably one of their finest concerts ever. And what a treat it had to have been for the 40,000 fans to witness, especially since this was the first visit to South America for Rush in their 30+ year history.  <br /> <br />The electricity of that evening translated well into the CD recording. At times, the deafening crowd is so powerful, so vibrant, that they wash over some of the music and vocals. Others complain about this type of 'distraction', but to me, this is a phenomenal way to truly feel like you're there, and not listening to a recording. If anything, I thought that the crowd energy wasn't fully represented on the CD as it was on the DVD. Part of that is certainly due to the visuals of the DVD focusing a lot of its attention on the crowd, where as the CD obviously would not have to live up to that aspect of the presentation. Still, the crowd interaction is quite vibrant and apparent throughout this triple CD, as they should be. After all, this is a LIVE CD. If you didn't want to hear the crowd, then go listen to the studio version :) That being said, I should point out that some songs suffer from washed out vocals more than others. Some adjustments to your system should improve the audio quality and separation, but at first listen, it may be difficult to pick up Geddy's vocals at a few select times.  <br /> <br />As mentioned above, this final show of the 2002 Vapor Trails tour was unquestionably one of the finest performances Rush had ever put forth, but as with all shows, there are always highlights, always particular songs that rise even farther above the bar. There's no shortage of those 'special' songs on this triple CD, but I thought it proper to discuss a few of the very best out of the collection of 30 available tracks.  <br /> <br />First, comes Tom Sawyer; the quintessential Rush song, and the one the boys chose to open up the concert on this tour. The anticipation of the crowd had piqued, so when Rush began playing the opening chords of this 20th century classic, the crowd absolutely erupted. Goose bumps? You bet. Turn this one up loud and become enveloped in the essence of the moment. Absolutely intense.  <br /> <br />Another amazing track comes in the form of YYZ, the superb instrumental that came from the same studio album (Moving Pictures - 1981) as Tom Sawyer. Once again, the crowd exploded with cheers as soon as the first instantly recognizable series of notes echoed out from Neil Peart's drum set. What became even more amazing was the fact that the crowd actually began to sing along to the song. Singing...to an instrumental...! We all hum to songs, but imagine 40,000 fans humming in unison. Simply amazing!  <br /> <br />One of Rush's staples at concerts throughout the years was the fan favorite Closer to the Heart. However for the Vapor Trails tour, Rush decided to retire this little ditty, that is until they went south of the border. They had heard that this was among the all-time favorite songs down south, so they decided to revive it for this special collection of fans. And upon Geddy Lee announcing this to the concert goers, they reacted with extreme appreciation. Having heard this song many times myself (live) and having had it appear on a couple of earlier live compilations, I wasn't expecting anything earth-shattering. But once again, Rush and the 40,000 other stars that night brought the song to new heights, instantly reaffirming what makes it such a popular song 25 years after it was first performed.  <br /> <br />Driven, from Rush's 'Test for Echo' album is just a solid jam, with Geddy at the helm. His spiritual and spontaneous bass rifts drive the scores of people wild. The vocals are spot-on, Alex's powerful guitars are electric (well, duh!) and Neil's heart-pounding punishment of his skins all work perfectly together. What a treat to behold. Perhaps a true candidate for a song that's better in its live format on its studio counterpart.  <br /> <br />O Baterista. Neil Peart. The Drum Solo. Words are completely inadequate in expressing the performance put forth here. Watching the impossible performance on the DVD was surreal. Hearing it again confirms my utter shock that one human being can have such a command over his percussion set up. Have you heard that Neil is regarded as one of the finest drummers of all time? Listen to this solo and hear exactly why.  <br /> <br />All of Disc 3 - every track, including the two 'soundboard' bootlegs are just incredible. A non-stop jam of incredible hits that Rush launches into. The fans go wild, never given a chance to rest after one song before the next is hurled at them at warp speed. Non-stop Rush elation best describes it. And, if you'll pardon the pun (or even if you don't), it's quite a Rush.  <br /> <br />Without question, Rush in Rio in both CD and DVD form should not be missed by any fan of this Canadian trio. And for those of you on the fence, have a listen. You'll be transported to a musical world unlike any other you've ever experienced.  <br /> <br />
B000005EJL|3.0|I came to this album not as a Supertramp fan but as a Mark Hart fan (yes, he has them) following his career after Crowded House.  I don't have the same breadth of knowledge about Supertramp, so I can't play the \\"I miss Roger, and the band is nothing without him\\" game that so many other reviewers seem to be doing. <br /> <br />Being the Mark fan that I am, I immediately focused on the songs that featured his vocals.  \\"Sooner or Later\\" is a great song that has a similar feel to Santana's \\"Oye Como Va\\".  I really like listening to the band members trading licks at the end of the song.  Likewise, I enjoyed \\"Give Me A Chance\\" (the \\"hidden\\" track before C'est What?) as a song featuring Mark.  On the other hand, I took an immediate dislike to \\"Listen to me Please\\" and have only made myself listen to it more because Mark is featured on it. <br /> <br />Hart's voice is good, but some material is not as kind to it as others.  If given the wrong thing, he can sound very whimpy and anonymous.  This album material almost dips into that territory.  To listen to something that does show Mark's strengths both vocally and instrumetally, invest in his solo album Nada Sonata. <br /> <br />Now to the rest.  I'm not much of a jazz fan, so if I don't get excited about what is on the album, that has a lot to do with it.  Also, the white-bread attempts at adding gospel elements just fail miserably.  I do have a few compliments, though. <br /> <br />*Rick Davies sounds his vocal best on \\"Live to Love You,\\" though the song itself is rather bland. <br /> <br />*The bass player, Cliff Hugo, is utterly AMAZING!  If I gained nothing else from following Mark Hart to this project, I learned about Cliff.  I want to hear more of this man's playing, and he is a new inspiration to me in my own playing. <br /> <br />*The same props to the horn section and percussion.  There are quite a few moments on this album where they take the blahs away because of playing so well. <br /> <br />So whatever your Supertramp issues, this is a decent album if taken on its own merits.  You'll like it if you enjoy jazzy elements.  You'll snore if you don't.  The best things about it for me are Mark and Cliff, and the rest is forgettable.

B00005JOHI|5.0|I hate to review the movie in such a fashion but invariably as a fan of the TV version, I initially (and errantly) made comparisons to that version and this film version. <br /> <br />Overall, I was rather pleased and surprised by my reaction to this film.  Granted with a listing of solid actors, I did not anticipate it being bad, but instead a bad interpretation of the book (which I have read a couple of times) especially given the time constraints that feature film provides. <br /> <br />While the 1995 TV version is quintessential in its adaptation of the text, the 2005 film version in my humble opinion captures the spirit and the raw emotion that although not on public display must have been in the hearts and minds of the central characters.  I guess this is what many folks consider the \\"modern edge\\" given to this adaptation.  I personally found it refreshing, vibrant and alive. <br /> <br />In terms of casting I must start by saying that I loved Keira Knightley's Lizzie - by far the best interpretation of the role.  And despite those who were blown away by the dashing Colin Firth, Matthew MacFadyen did the role of Darcy service.  His performance wonderfully gives perspective and insight into the perceived fastidiousness of the Darcy persona - I felt like in this version I understood where he is coming from. <br /> <br />Beyond the two leads, all the supporting characters did a wonderful job.  I am almost tempted to go to the theater and see it again it was that good.  Highly recommended to all! <br />

1400043662|3.0|To begin with a major annoyance, the English translation by Prof. Philip Gabriel of Murakami Haruki's Kafka On the Shore has been excessively \\"britishized\\" for the first Vintage paperback edition. The result is a weird mixture of American syntax and style with British spelling, typography, and vocabulary (mobile phones, lorries, and torches abound). Alas, this mixture isn't just weird and off-putting: it's effectively out-pulling insofar as the translation's constant flow of linguistic inconsistencies pulls you right out of the story, time and again. It's a great example of what I've come to call the \\"Transparency With Birds\\" effect. Meanwhile, Vintage also issued Gabriel's original translation in a \\"reprint\\" paperback edition, so both that and the original hardcover edition are an option.<br /><br />The story itself can wrap you up & take you away, but Kafka on the Shore is certainly not among Haruki's masterpieces. The story lines are excessively opaque and excessively predictable at the same time, the characters at once over- and underdeveloped, and the novel has a Stephen King-ish feeling about it (certain motifs, characters, modes of progression), but without King's knack for weaving even the most outlandish storylines into a gripping and satisfying solution. Not that Kafka On the Shore needed a solution, but it also lacks internal coherence. In the end, too many things and events have not been accounted for, neither in terms of a solution nor in terms of coherence. And certainly not in terms of development: especially Kafka Tamura, the principal character with first-person view (mostly), seems to have ended up right where he started, up to and including his fully intact alter ego that goes by the name of \\"Crow.\\"<br /><br />The story's development, like the characters', is designed to be labyrinthine---a recurrent motif---rather than linear. Only, it's more circular than labyrinthine, on balance. While both the phrases \\"wrong turns must be righted\\" and \\"wrong turns have been righted\\" turn up sufficiently often in the original paperback edition's 615 pages to suggest one must have missed some major plot point or other, it is close to impossible even after attempts at backtracking to pinpoint what wrong turns have been taken when by which characters, let alone righted. That's postmodern, alright. Speaking of which, there's also that typically postmodern mix of ancient archetypes and corporate conspiracy elements, complete with a more than decent load of learned detours into art & culture, but without the tightly controlled over-the-top playfulness of, like, John Barth's or Donald Barthelme's or Robert Coover's fiction. Plus, Murakami's use of feminist characters and corporate icons feels forced, heavy-handed, and artificial. At times, the heavy-handedness even affects his writing technique: the way two pseudo-feminist cardboard characters \\"function\\" to reveal important attributes of another important character's make-up (Oshima) borders on hack work.1<br /><br />But still, Kafka on the Shore is a rich and gripping reading experience. It does expand one's understanding of the world, or at least one's repertoire of questions. But of weaknesses, alas, it has more than its fair share.<br /><br />>> This review has been updated on Dec. 8, 2009. The updated review was originally published at my blog [...].righted\\" turn up sufficiently often in the original paperback edition's 615 pages to suggest one must have missed some major plot point or other, it is close to impossible even after attempts at backtracking to pinpoint what wrong turns have been taken when by which characters, let alone righted. That's postmodern, alright. Speaking of which, there's also that typically postmodern mix of ancient archetypes and corporate conspiracy elements, complete with a more than decent load of learned detours into art & culture, but without the tightly controlled over-the-top playfulness of, like, John Barth's or Donald Barthelme's or Robert Coover's fiction. Plus, Murakami's use of feminist characters and corporate icons feels forced, heavy-handed, and artificial. At times, the heavy-handedness even affects his writing technique: the way two pseudo-feminist cardboard characters \\"function\\" to reveal important attributes of another important character's make-up (Oshima) borders on hack work.1    But still, Kafka on the Shore is a rich and gripping reading experience. It does expand one's understanding of the world, or at least one's repertoire of questions. But of weaknesses, alas, it has more than its fair share.    >> This review has been updated on Dec. 8, 2009. The updated review was originally published at my blog [...].

B00005B36H|5.0|I'm an avid Maynard fan. I'm eagerly awaiting their newest release set to drop early next year (Maybe January?). Until then, I've finally decided to write an online review for their masterpiece, Lateralus.<br /><br />Its hard to decide if Lateralus is better then Aenima. After each listen, I lean towards Lateralus as being just a complete dream, a euphoric one where I'm complacent and relaxed. Aenima has more edge, and definitley more anger. Lateralus will take you where Aenima and Undertow couldn't. It wasn't their purpose. Right from the start, you are brought into \\"The Grudge.\\" An 8 minute classic that sets the tone for the rest of the disc....at least you think so. The song prepares you for the unknown, because as soon as its over, you drop into the Eon Blue Apocalypse, a minute long transition that sets up \\"The Patient\\" a musical orgasm that you would not have expected. Usually with custom albums, the second song launches you into a different direction. Sticking with Maynard, look at \\"Mer de Noms\\" with The Hollow, followed by Magdalena. Two different approaches to music it seems. But enough about APC, back to Lateralus. The Patient has potential to move you in ways that The Grudge couldn't. Its musically enchanting, and lyrically superior to The Grudge, though by no means \\"better\\" since they are all part of the experience. \\"Mantra\\" carries you over to the first single off of Lateralus.<br /><br />\\"Schism\\" hooks you right from the moment it starts. There is no warning and it just sucks you in. Maynard haunts you here. His voicem, similar to when he begins in \\"The Grudge\\" is very forceful, but delicate. He lets you know that you are in for a ride. You get blasted 3/4 of the way through with the edge that was missing from \\"The Patient.\\" And to make it all the more worth while...it drops off into \\"Parabol.\\" Usually a CD will have one major climax, and that be it. Not Lateralus. Repeated climactic areas occur on this album, and that is a hint for some people not ready for it, to put the album back on the shelf and leave the store. But those willing to keep going, follow into the 3rd climax as \\"Parabol\\" hits \\"Parabola\\" and we are taken through one of the most intriguing and genuinely amazing tracks that Tool's ever produced. The two combined were a single (though most radio stations started \\"Parabol\\" at the 2:55 mark, just in time for the climax into \\"Parabola\\") It doesn't end there either.<br /><br />\\"Ticks & Leeches\\" screams potential. Maynard has been noted to have scorched his chords on this one while edging out the screams. That's intense. Much like the transition from \\"Schism\\" to \\"Parabol\\" there's a drop off mid song, that just sends you down the stream, with a little bit of string to hold you on. Then, when you're just about completely submerged, they pull you out of that trance for the next climax, and close out this amazing track.<br /><br />\\"Lateralus\\" the title track is my personal favorite. Cracking in at over 9 minutes long, I think it represents the style of Tool much more then anything else on the album. \\"Black and white are, all I see, in my infancy\\" it sets up the transitions between Maynard's vocals and the rest of the bands punctuality with him. Its not sporadic, its all purposeful, and thats what sets them apart from a lot of other bands. They take time to write it, and dont rush it, thats why there's a good amount of time between each release. To see this song live was amazing, and Danny Carey made sure you got everything you paid for with his solo to finish us off. A masterpiece.<br /><br />Its not over yet though. Considered to be one long track just broken up, Tracks 10-12 all seem to share a similar theme to them. \\"Disposition\\" is the four and a half minute under balanced track, composed of the same lyrics, over a hypnotic melody. I've often found myself, falling asleep here. Not because I was bored, but because I was relaxed. This is Maynard letting you drift off and relax. But not for long, though \\"Reflection\\" is an extension of \\"Disposition\\" it seems at times, its by no means boring. It keeps the theme moving right along of Lateralus, making the listener believe that what they've just listened to, the last 10 tracks, to be the end of this intense ride through the mind. Until you hit around 6 minutes of this 11 minute track, and Maynard brings you back in. Then its \\"Triad\\" which uses many hard guitars to bring you back in for the final climax. Intense, predominantly instrumental, but completely fitting for the end. Because after \\"Triad\\"...you're left with the lonely frantic blubberings of a former Area 51 officer in \\"Faaip De Oiad\\" ...which I'm sure is actually a joke.<br /><br />The actual climaxes happen here: The Patient (about 3 minutes or so in), Schism (half way through or so), Parabol/Parabola transition, Ticks and Leeches drop off, then resurface, almost all of Lateralus (track 9), and during Triad.<br /><br />So there you have it, Lateralus. What many consider to be the greatest Tool album ever. Others believe its pure garbage. I on the other hand have to agree that it is quite amazing and beautiful. I can't argue with those who see it as near perfect. There's a common misconception about Tool being Satan worshippers, and its all nonsense. In fact, they pray before every meal. They just encourage you to think for yourself, and question authority. Five stars, doesn't do this justice. It should be in everyones possession, to be enjoyed, and experienced. If you haven't, you should. If you have, you know exactly what I'm talking about.ong, though \\"Reflection\\" is an extension of \\"Disposition\\" it seems at times, its by no means boring. It keeps the theme moving right along of Lateralus, making the listener believe that what they've just listened to, the last 10 tracks, to be the end of this intense ride through the mind. Until you hit around 6 minutes of this 11 minute track, and Maynard brings you back in. Then its \\"Triad\\" which uses many hard guitars to bring you back in for the final climax. Intense, predominantly instrumental, but completely fitting for the end. Because after \\"Triad\\"...you're left with the lonely frantic blubberings of a former Area 51 officer in \\"Faaip De Oiad\\" ...which I'm sure is actually a joke.  <br /> <br />The actual climaxes happen here: The Patient (about 3 minutes or so in), Schism (half way through or so), Parabol/Parabola transition, Ticks and Leeches drop off, then resurface, almost all of Lateralus (track 9), and during Triad.  <br /> <br />So there you have it, Lateralus. What many consider to be the greatest Tool album ever. Others believe its pure garbage. I on the other hand have to agree that it is quite amazing and beautiful. I can't argue with those who see it as near perfect. There's a common misconception about Tool being Satan worshippers, and its all nonsense. In fact, they pray before every meal. They just encourage you to think for yourself, and question authority. Five stars, doesn't do this justice. It should be in everyones possession, to be enjoyed, and experienced. If you haven't, you should. If you have, you know exactly what I'm talking about.

0553801503|4.0|I read this right after reading Robert Jordan's latest and was far more entertained with \\"Crows\\". Jordan could use some lessons from Martin on narrative pacing. Martin does seem to slow down the plot a bit, assumingly to set the stage for future books. I think this is faithful to how the \\"real world\\" works, but doesn't make for the most exciting reading at times.  <br /> <br />But Martin's real strength is character development and I think he is true to form here. Really enjoyed the development of Jaime as a character - no he doesn't do much but you get some much needed insight to his motivations and character.  <br /> <br />The book missed Tyrion and Danerys however, my favorite characters from the previous books. They add a lot of depth to the story line and I found myself wanting to skip chapters in the previous books to pick up their stories again. <br /> <br />Also, the brutality gets a bit overwhelming at times. What was a realistic, refreshing change over the faeryland fodder out there a few years ago seems over the top now. Maybe it's Martin, maybe it's me... <br /> <br />Definitely worth a read though
B0009HLDFU|4.0|First of all, this disc is outstanding; an entire CD of uncompromising hard rock, coupled with an excellent acoustic disc.  This allows the band to go to both extremes without worrying about spacing softer songs between loud rockers.  I have the rock CD on my MP3 player for working out, and the soft CD in the \\"dinner music\\" lineup with Norah Jones (who also does a cameo on the album).  Pure genius. <br /> <br />Wait; did I say MP3 player?  YES!!  All these militant I-Pod freaks that are wailing about the copy protection have fallen victim to Apple's insistence on using the dreaded \\"proprietary technology\\" for their I tunes/I Pod business.  I have a relatively cheap I-River MP3 player and had no probem putting the Foo Fighters CD on the player.  Nearly all non-Apple MP3 players can support the protected DRM-WMA file format contained on this disc.  Here's how it works... <br /> <br />When you put the CD into the computer, it loads in the songs via its own software (and yes, you can choose not to install it, and no there is no spyware or \\"cyberterrorism\\" attached).  You then tranfer all songs as WMA files with the accompanying licenses.  Once you have done this, you can transfer the files to your MP3 player, and yes even burn them to a CD!!  The only thing you cannot do is Email the tracks or put them on a Kazaa style file sharing network!! <br /> <br />The only trick is, in order to put the songs on your MP3 player you must use Windows Media Player, not the software that came with the MP3 player.  My \\"Iriver manager\\" cannot transfer the DRM licenses so the tracks won't play.  There is a help menu as soon as you load in the CD that explains everything. <br /> <br />So now the I-Pod users know how I felt when I purchased $30 worth of songs on I tunes, only to find that they are not true MP3 files and therefore would not play on regular MP3 players like mine!  Since Apple will not permit these \\"M4p\\" files to play on non-Ipod players, then it's only fair that the Windowsbased copy protection won't play on Apple's players.  For those of us who opted to purchase one of the dozens of non-Apple MP3 players, there is no problem!!
B00002Z88D|5.0|This album truly builds upon the Metallica songs in ways I never thought possible. The symphony sounds like it was made to be there on the orginal tracks, which many Metallica fans know quite well already. Songs like Master of Puppets, The Thing That Should Not Be, For Whom the Bell Tolls, Wherever I May Roam, Enter Sandman, and Battery stand out already on their albums, so the biggest surprise is what the the symphonic accompaniment does for lesser Metallica tracks. Many people criticize Load and Reload for weaker songs (I agree, especially on Reload, which I refuse to purchase), but tracks like Fuel, The Memory Remains, Devil's Dance (ok Black Album there), and Bleeding Me finally become redeeming because of the energy in the fantastic symphonic additions. Tracks from the Black Album end up improved as well, but not as dramatically as later works. Finally, Metallica proves they still can write excellent songs (circa 1999) with No Leaf Clover and Human. <br /> <br />This is a solid album, and I highly recommend it for any Metallica fan.

B000026OHN|5.0|I have long held Richter to be a master of baroque music and polyphonic music in general. Since fugues are a model for conflicting layered themes and their intertwining with other themes, this music can be very difficult and a surprising number of pianists cannot master them. Richter is very serious in anything he plays and you can see that throughout the cycle he is very consistent and never gets lazy. This is what makes Richter so special.... is his mastery and understanding of braod genres of music ( a legitimate criticism, I guess to a certain extent, to Horowitz and Rubinstien who molded their repertoire to suit what they played well). Richter's Baroque is very different than conventional Baroque - more intense, less benign, even agressive at times. I guess it is worthwhile to hold a view versions if one wishes - harpsichord, Richter, maybe Schiff. Overall, this CD is close to my heart.

It seemed like around every corner some character was rememering when something happened, then followed what that incident was.  Interesting is what is currently happening in the story along with a few glimpses of the past.  I think it unnecessary to continuously flashback over, and over, and over again. <br /> <br />- I am a firm believer that chapters should add something relevant to the story.  There were many chapters where I felt that if I did not read them I would not have missed anything.  Other chapters did reveal something of the story but the revelation was so minor - and usually found on the last page - that I wondered what the other 14 pages of the chapter were for. <br /> <br />- I felt with this release, Martin knew he had his readers hooked.  Knowing that, he wrote this book to add to the overall story, only, for the most part the additions were minor.  An editor could have easily chopped out much of the unnecessary descriptions and horse ridings and conferences and pointless dialogues and combined this with Dance  - making it one novel.  That Martin released this (after such a long period in between), is a pretty big let down.  I found myself reading not because I wanted to, but because I was interested in finishing the story all the way through Dance.  Martin needs to stop showing off his ability to make up names andsigils and just continue doing what he was doing in the beginning. <br /> <br />Suggestion to readers:  If you have not read the other books, get them and devour them - they are wonderful.  When you get to this one, look for a cliffnote or an abridged version - or, better yet, ask someone who read it what happens.  save yourself the time and just hope that Dance returns to the original formula that made this a great story in the first place.  Thanks.

B00081U6EG|3.0|Well the idea SOUNDED fantastic: Celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Fender Stratocaster with a live concert featuring some of its greatest practitioners.  Unfortunately somewhere between conceptualization and realization, things went horribly wrong.  Now maybe I'm not aware of the logistics needed to pull off such an event, but even a monkey with a bag over his head could've picked a better set of names.  I WILL give the organizers this though, they struck platinum when they landed David Gilmour, easily one of THE premiere guitar gods to be associated with the Strat (or ANY guitar for that matter).  Likewise Gary Moore.  Though considered a Les Paul man since 1990, Gary has abused quite a few strats throughout his hard rock/metal days so he easily qualifies.  And to be fair, they supposedly had the legendary Jeff Beck signed as well (certainly another of the greatest EVER) but somehow managed to lose him in the end.  From there, things rapidly deteriorated to the point of complete confusion.  Where was Robin Trower??  It's been said that he's been staying close to home due to touring costs.  And Ritchie Blackmore??  Couldn't anyone convince him to plug in again for just one night??  How about Mark Knopfler??  Buddy Guy??  What about young guns Joe Bonamassa, Chris Duarte, and Kenny Wayne Shepherd??  Didn't anyone think of buying Eric Johnson a plane ticket???  Unfortunately, oversights like these made for a rather disappointing show.  If you're a guitar-playing music fan looking for strat players to show you how it's done, you'll have to wade through a lot of junk to get to the good stuff.  But enough whining; here are the highlights:  <br /> <br />For me, the whole reason to buy this DVD is David Gilmour, who took the stage to a standing ovation.  The crowd was not disappointed.  Although he looked a bit thrown off by the house band at times (some cues were missed by the band during the free time intros to two of the songs), once he settled in he just soared.  Without question, of all the acts that night, Dave displayed the widest array of sonic possibilities a stratocaster can offer: bending strings; caressing the whammy bar; using volume swells; feedback touches; playing behind the nut; all the while blending lush liquid melodic lines with searing hot earth-shaking licks.  I've certainly seen him perform these songs better, but even \\"mediocre Gilmour\\" is stunning.  The next reason to pick this DVD up is Gary Moore.  Another astounding player, Gary performed a barn burning version of Red House, taking his battered strat from hushed whispers to absolutely blazing runs in the blink of an eye.  Like Gilmour, he demonstrated how much can be done with the instrument in his way-too-brief set (I highly recommend picking up his Live at Montreaux DVD as well as tracking down his two flawless out-of-print VHS shows).  Other highlights include Hank Marvin, whose simple but silky lines decorated with light whammy bar touches really showcased the gorgeous pure tone of the stratocaster.  His set was a nice surprise and clearly illustrated why he was such a hero to many of England's greatest players.  Then there was Albert Lee who lit up an otherwise dull moment by pop/country act Theresa Anderson.  Lee's flashy chicken pickin' during Country Boy was a brief highlight of this otherwise dreary set.  Phil Manzenera was another nice surprise.  He played a mid-tempo instrumental with a slight Eastern flavor, taking advantage of the strat's tremolo bar.  I would've liked to have heard more.   <br /> <br />The extras here include interviews with some of the performers reminiscing about their first encounter with the Fender Strat and how it changed them.  I found this segment rather enjoyable.  If you are a guitar player yourself, you will likely relate to a lot of the comments and may develop a sudden urge to go shopping for a 2-tone sunburst strat with a blonde neck.   <br /> <br />So bottom line, is this worth it?  Well like most \\"star studded\\" concert discs, you will likely watch the full show once and then find yourself just jumping around to your favorite cuts later on.  How many cuts are worth jumping to is obviously up to your own personal taste.  All in all this is basically a fair DVD that could've been miles better.  As a final thought, if you're on the fence and need just one good reason to drop some cash on this, remember that the proceeds go to Nordoff-Robbins Musical Therapy.  And that's not a bad reason at all. <br />

0061015725|4.0|Like most Michael Crichton books, this one is a fun, fast, exciting read.  I give it 3.5 stars.  PREY is a \\"Frankenstein\\" story about nanotechnology/biotechnology/computer technology run amok... but it also borrows themes from INVASION OF THE BODY SNATCHERS, and the campy 60's TV series VOYAGE TO THE BOTTOM OF THE SEA (where every week one or more of the crewmembers is \\"taken over by aliens\\").<br /><br />The story includes some very strong character development, and it is easy to relate with the main character Jack's plight througout the story.  Jack is an out-of-work high-tech Silicon Valley software manager, who is playing Mr. Mom, while his wife is trying to score big by hooking some big Venture Capital money in the fledgling nanotechnology industry... she and others at her company are very agressive and competitive - too much for their own good, it turns out.<br /><br />The biggest problems I had with the book were related to a number of unbelievable scenarios.  For example, the scenes involving the \\"dirt bike\\" were totally unbelievable - the way the scene is described, I kept imagining these two big guys trying to get on the equivalent of a Japanese 70cc 2-stroke pit bike, which he \\"pulls out of the trunk\\" of a vehicle... it would have bottomed out the suspension!  and even that bike wouldn't have needed the all-important \\"missing key\\"... and he \\"straddles the bike and starts if up\\"??? electric start on a small dirt bike?? ... and then, it has a light?... so maybe it was a like a modern 650cc 4-stroke enduro??? It makes no sense - that bike's suspension would be WAY too tall for the described antics to have transpired, and how could he pull the bike out of the trunk so easy then, and how could he have started a 4-stroke so fast - after he had LAID IT ON THE GROUND! ... nope - COULDN'T have happened the way it was described - no way, no how.  And, there were other unbelievable scenes like with the wind changing speed from calm to very gusty, up and down, throughout a whole day (obviously because it suited the flow of the story) - I've lived in the high desert, and it aint gonna happen how it was described.<br /><br />Michael Crichton goes to great lengths to do research on the high-tech subjects in his books (look at the footnotes and bibliography), but then he goofs up on simple everyday technology like \\"dirt bikes\\" and \\"desert winds\\"... man, he could just have taken 1 day to go out in the desert and research what it is like to ride a dirt bike, and to know what the winds are really like... or just talk to someone about this stuff.(obviously because it suited the flow of the story) - I've lived in the high desert, and it aint gonna happen how it was described. B0009S2T0M|5.0|After a night of drinking, a man is imprisoned by some unknown people and left there for 15 years until he's let out.  After a while trying to readjust to society and figure out what's happened, he is given 5 days to wreak vengeance upon whoever took his life away from him.  Unfortunately, the progress is being watched by a less than benevolent spectator.<br /><br />What's interesting about this film is it's influences.  It's based loosely around The Count of Monte Cristo, takes a lot of Shakespearian and Biblical elements, throws in typical Asian kung fu, and then puts it into a very modern stylistic context in terms of cinema.  The best part about this movie's style is that it never actually feels overdone and it actually seems to make sense...  a shot isn't canted just to be weird, it's more subtle than that, even if the tone itself bleeds the idea of style.<br /><br />Honestly, I was taken simply by a single shot, a long take where the camera tracks along a hallway as the main character fights off a large group of people.  It straddles the line between realism and romance and creates a distructive ballet of choreography and motion that is downright beautiful in a somewhat horrible way.  Then setting it into the context it has to a rather well done and structured story really helps this movie have a profound effect on the viewer.  Just don't expect to be coming out of this feeling very happy, as it gets a bit disturbing at the end.<br /><br />It may have overdone the ending, but I don't care.  The weird mix of hypnosis and not-hypnosis kind of constricted the story.  It is interesting to note that this film is of a new group of films out there that a few people call Asian Extreme Cinema, and I've seen two other films from this neo-genre that involve heavy use of violence and hypnosis themes (and men cutting their own tongues out).  Why do these images seem to tie this genre together? So all of these negative reviews here from 'the dedicated fans' have amazed me. It seems that there are two different \\"Amarantine\\" copies in circulation, because it's beyond my comprehension how anyone can give this record a one star and still love Enya's previous works.    Enya is enya, she's doing music which has her character all over it. If she would change her style, that would not be Enya anymore. And what kind of changes in her style she is supposed to make? A country record perhaps? Or techno? Please... Those who find her repetitive, I think it's a bit too late to say it after the 6th album. I would have stopped listening her ten years ago, and not bothered to try her albums anymore.    And this album is no way \\"A Day Without Rain part II\\". Many things have changed from that record. There is only one instrumental this time, when others had three. There is no Latin, but Japanese and Loxian, a totally new language created by a lyricist Roma Ryan. All songs Enya sang by Loxian are quite different in styles than on \\"A Day Without Rain\\". \\"Less Than a Pearl\\" could have been on \\"The Celts\\" album, \\"The River Sings\\" is a bit like \\"Ebudae\\" from \\"Shepherd Moons\\". \\"Water Shows the Hidden Heart\\" is one of Enya's finest moments in her whole career. I think she has not made anything similar before. It's like an aria from Puccini's opera with some church music feeling. Enya's voice is also more prominent this time and sounds lovelier than ever.    If you are an Enya-devotee, I think you are aware of the fact that everyone of her album'shas its own mood and color. The fact that each of her albums has their own admirers, tells that she has no weak records in her catalogue. You may not like each of them equally, but that's just a matter of taste. \\"Amarantine\\" is not going to be everone's favorite Enya album, but the fact is that it's just as enjoyable as the rest of them. There is no-one quite like Enya, and let's be happy that she's giving us something unique from her music. The gaps between her records may be long, but remember that it takes a long time to make an Enya-album. And that time is always worth waiting for, and this time is no exception.
B0006J28MI|4.0|Richie Rich is the world's poor little rich boy. He's the richest kid on Earth, but all he really wants are friends (well, he's got everything else). He spends his days living by a meticulous schedule that sometimes even includes filling in for his father at public appearances. His wealthy schoolmates are just as busy as he is and not quite as desperate to do \\"regular kid things\\" as Richie. While filling in for his father at a public event, however, Richie takes notice of some inner-city, street-wise kids playing baseball in a vacant lot nearby and makes an attempt to join in. They soon make it clear that he does not belong, and poor Richie goes home in despair. Seeing his disappointment, Richie's protective and caring butler, Cadbury, makes arrangements for the kids to come to the Rich family mansion and spend a day with the boy, much to Richie's joy and surprise! The gang of kids have a ball riding Richie's rollercoaster, trying out his kid-a-pult, and eating in his own, personal McDonald's. At the end of the day, Richie's new friends have accepted him as being just another regular kid, though they more than appreciate the benefits that come with his friendship. Still, feisty redhead Gloria, self-appointed leader of the bunch, makes it clear that they like Richie more for who he is than for all the neat stuff he has. Richie doesn't have much time to be happy about that, though. Word soon arrives that Richie's parents, benign but sometimes clueless Richard and Regina Rich, were victims of an assassination attempt and are now lost at sea and assumed dead. As the Riches survive in a life raft on Perrier and champagne, Richie is forced to take over the family company and keep it safe from malicious top executive Lawrence Van Dough, who planned the attack on Richie's parents in the first place. Luckily, with his new friends' help, Richie turns out to be a business whiz! Richie has to become even more assertive when Cadburry is framed and locked up for the murder of Richie's parents though. Some help from in-house inventor Professor Keenbean allows Richie to break Cadburry out, but matters become even more complicated when the Rich parents finally are rescued by the villainous Van Dough and his cronies themselves, purely so they can open the voice-activated lock on the family vault in Mt. Richmore. Now, Richie and his crew must prove their mettle and save Richie's parents and fortune from a criminal desperate to do anything to have it all!<br /><br />After the wonderful holiday films \\"Home Alone\\" and \\"Home Alone 2\\" turned child-actor Macaulay Culkin into an instant superstar, he sadly seemed incapable of having another success. 1994's \\"Richie Rich\\" was just one example of several films the young actor made after his big Christmas hits that failed to strike a chord with movie going audiences or critics. Sadly, \\"Richie Rich\\" is really a great film. While not a perfect adaptation of the comic and cartoon (the villainous Van Dough is an adult exec here rather than a rotten cousin, Gloria is unfortunately a cute but street-sassy tomboy with a last-name change rather than Richie's sweet and femininely dressed girlfriend, and Irona the robot maid/bodyguard is nowhere to be seen until the direct to video \\"sequel\\"), the performances, particularly the adult ones, are fantastic, fun, well developed and well fleshed-out considering their cartoon origins, and easily carry the very basic cartoon plot. The humor and emotion is well-written, even if it's an age-old story of the rich kid who just wants friends. And, of course, the sights are the icing on the cake, from the kooky inventions of Professor Keenbean to the glorious Rich Family Estate (actually the Biltmore Estate in North Carolina), not to mention the world's only Dollarmation, Richie's dog, Dollar! The DVD is in widescreen and includes one Bonus Feature, which is the theatrical trailer. Hey, \\"Richie Rich\\" isn't rocket science, but it's a feast for the eyes and a fun family fantasy frohie's parents though. Some help from in-house inventor Professor Keenbean allows Richie to break Cadburry out, but matters become even more complicated when the Rich parents finally are rescued by the villainous Van Dough and his cronies themselves, purely so they can open the voice-activated lock on the family vault in Mt. Richmore. Now, Richie and his crew must prove their mettle and save Richie's parents and fortune from a criminal desperate to do anything to have it all! <br /> <br />After the wonderful holiday films \\"Home Alone\\" and \\"Home Alone 2\\" turned child-actor Macaulay Culkin into an instant superstar, he sadly seemed incapable of having another success. 1994's \\"Richie Rich\\" was just one example of several films the young actor made after his big Christmas hits that failed to strike a chord with movie going audiences or critics. Sadly, \\"Richie Rich\\" is really a great film. While not a perfect adaptation of the comic and cartoon (the villainous Van Dough is an adult exec here rather than a rotten cousin, Gloria is unfortunately a cute but street-sassy tomboy with a last-name change rather than Richie's sweet and femininely dressed girlfriend, and Irona the robot maid/bodyguard is nowhere to be seen until the direct to video \\"sequel\\"), the performances, particularly the adult ones, are fantastic, fun, well developed and well fleshed-out considering their cartoon origins, and easily carry the very basic cartoon plot. The humor and emotion is well-written, even if it's an age-old story of the rich kid who just wants friends. And, of course, the sights are the icing on the cake, from the kooky inventions of Professor Keenbean to the glorious Rich Family Estate (actually the Biltmore Estate in North Carolina), not to mention the world's only Dollarmation, Richie's dog, Dollar! The DVD is in widescreen and includes one Bonus Feature, which is the theatrical trailer. Hey, \\"Richie Rich\\" isn't rocket science, but it's a feast for the eyes and a fun family fantasy from beginning to end that brings back childhood memories of Saturday morning cartoons and Harvey comics, and with actors like Edward Herrmann, John Larroquette, and Jonathan Hyde in a live-action cartoon, you know you're in for a treat!   <br />

Should she run off with the handsome blond or with the dynamic stranger who is a natty dresser, has an incredible, ah, lair, and is a genius to boot?  His deformity makes him additionally appealing - one's heart goes out to him.<br /><br />3) The over-the-top sets are visually rich and enjoyable.<br /><br />4) Emmy Rossum has a SUPERIOR voice and is enchanting to look at. No.  The sword fight is absurd and unnecessary.  The fall of the chandelier should have been better (watch Disk II for a better scene of the infamous fall!).<br /><br />8) All the versions of Phantom suffer from the following but few if any have commented: each of Christine's suitors treats her like an object and a child.  Even though the Phantom got my vote as The One To Run Off With in the movie, I fantasize about Christine dumping both guys and seeking a man who didn't objectify her!
015603008X|5.0|In the world that we live in, nothing is impossible. <br /> <br /> In Daniel Keyes' book, Flowers for Algernon, the \\"impossible\\" comes true. Despite the simple story, Keyes presents a tragic yet miraculous story that triggers feelings of anger, pity, and humor all at the same time. The unexpected plot twists keep the reader interested throughout the book. Keyes truly touches one's heart with the honest and direct feelings in his story and the valuable lesson it teaches. <br />  <br /> Charlie Gordon, the main character, is a mentally challenged, middle-aged man who worked as a sweeper at a nearby bakery. Although he faces discrimination, humiliation, and taunting from fellow workers, he does not realize them as such due to his limited IQ level. The tables turn, however, when Charlie is offered to participate in an experiment that will increase his IQ greatly. Previously only tested on a lab rat named Algernon, Charlie would be the first human to undergo the same procedure. This experiment successfully turns Charlie into a genius. Charlie is able to discover surprising details about his earlier life as well as a new love life. However, to his dismay, Charlie soon finds out that being smart is not everything. His newfound intelligence leads to an isolation much like his lack of intelligence had before. In the height of all the drama, Algernon the lab rat dies. <br /> <br /> Keyes used the technique of a journal entry to tell the story. The straightforward writing style effectively showed the metamorphosis of Charlie and the people around him. The technique of foreshadowing, which hints at what is to come, worked marvelously in this book to move the story along. But as the ending draws near, it is heartbreaking to see the deterioration of his newly gained intelligence fading more and more until it no longer exists.  <br /> <br /> Keyes sends many messages and emotions throughout the book, but it the honesty of his tone that makes this story both so believable and exciting. Because of this depth of emotion Flowers for Algernon, is one of the best books I have read.  <br />
B000BOH8XW|5.0|Capping off a year in which Shakira had the #1 single and album on the Latin charts and made history by becoming the highest charting Spanish album in Billboard history, Shakira delivers her second set of delights on this lavish and tasty set. <br /> <br />    It's hard to separate both \\"Fixations\\" Vol. 1 and 2, they are both different albums and even Shakira herself will tell you that they have no preset connection to one another. But take that concept away and listen to both as different albums, we can come to understand and appreciate them separately, because both albums have very distinct sounds. \\"Oral Fixation 2\\" is a traditional mixture (at least in her music) of College Rock and Dance Pop...and her 80's synth tones, first heard on \\"Vol. 1\\". However, this second set oozes with psycoanalitical and socialogic lyrics, spitting out venom about the world and certain governments in general. This in no way distracts from the beautiful production of the music, as it never overwhelms the music. Shakira obviously understands the balance that pop stars need to understand when making pop music and diving in to political subjects. You have to have lyrics that speak your truth but at the same time understand that the melody of the song needs to be solid enough to sell to the popular music world. \\"Oral Fixation 2\\" is a great example of this and stands out with great social conscious-pop records like Janet Jackson's \\"Rhythm Nation\\" and Marvin Gaye's \\"What's Going On\\". I'm glad Shakira knew what she was doing and understood that the MUSIC was the selling point...she could have easily crashed and burned and release a disastrous record. So many others have tried and failed to release social conscious pop but end up frustrating themselves and the market...who can remember Madonna's similiar attempt \\"American Life\\"?  <br /> <br />    This record is not entirely political...it sneaks in some beautiful love songs. My particular favorite and the song that stood out from the rest,probably because of its RnB influences, was the lovely \\"Dreams For Plans\\". Shakira's frustrations on love   <br />are beautifully spoken of when asking \\"Did I change my hopes for fears and my dreams for plans?\\". I'm sure this is a subject many people can identify with. And then of course there's the 2 English versions of songs first heard on \\"Fijacion Oral V. 1\\". \\"The Day and The Time\\" is nice..but the original \\"Dia Especial\\" is superior and also Gustavo Cerati's voice is much more evident. \\"Something\\" is lovely, but it lacks the passion of Shakira's voice in the original \\"En Tus Pupilas\\". Both songs are touching tributes to someone who has seeped in to your skin. <br /> <br />     I'm sure it will be a welcome suprise to many of her English fans who are expecting Shakira upbeat material. I'm sure people will be bopping to \\"Animal City\\" and the synth-pop \\"Timor\\". This album doesn't have any of that \\"la da da da do day\\" or Reggaeton babbling of \\"La Tortura\\" but it doesn't fail to make you want to shake your shimmy. You'll be happy to listen to a great pop album that doesn't try too hard to impress

B000000OSE|5.0|For the common rock fan, the term \\"Guns n' Roses\\" is synonymous with \\"Appettite for Destruction.\\"<br /><br />Rarely are the follow-up double albums, Use Your Illusion I & II even mentioned today among the casual fan.<br /><br />But, the diehard G'n'R fan such as myself know better. In the G'n'R fan forums of today, which together boast tens of thousands of daily visitors, the general consensus is that the Illusion albums deserve in their own right to be named one of hard rock's finest achievements.<br /><br />Critic reviews of the albums were poor due to both albums having a good amount of \\"filler\\" which I, even as the most hardcore of fans, find true. The Use Your Illusion's or UYI's for short, are not albums that I can find myself listening straight through like Appettite. In fact, I don't think I've ever even heard some of the songs more than once.<br /><br />But for those songs that have left a lasting impression, I will touch on them briefly.<br /><br />Use Your Illusion I is the harder rocker of the two Illusion's. Songs include:<br /><br />\\"Dust N' Bones\\" which is a fine example of a laid-back rocker that features a catchy end chorus long with a solid guitar solo.<br /><br />\\"Live N Let Die\\" - a single off the album and cover of the Paul McCartney classic. Although the studio version is nowhere near as good as seeing this song performed live, it'll still leave you with a desire to see the Bond flick.<br /><br />\\"Don't Cry\\" - Izzy's power ballad which features a very powerful message, a tear-dropping solo from Slash, and an absolutely memorable ending with both the majestic vocals and riffs.<br /><br />\\"Double Talkin' Jive\\" - an Izzy rocker that although only 2-3 minutes in length, makes you want more. A song that's expanded to 14-15 minutes in length live, DTJ is an absolute unknown as far as great g'n'r rockers go. The ending to the song features a Spanish guitar tune that is reminiscent of the Eagles' 'Hotel California.'<br /><br />\\"November Rain\\" - greatest ballad of all-time, no competition. No one who thinks November Rain is not a great song has heard it enough times to respect it for what it is - a masterpiece. Axl's ode to undying love is a build-up of majestic proportions. Everything about the song is perfect from its beginning piano piece to the slow vocal buildup to the guitar solos to the classic outro.<br /><br />\\"Coma\\" - my personal favorite G'n'R tune at the moment. If you haven't already listened to this song 3-5 times on full volume - please do so, I promise you that you won't be disappointed. The last 3 and 1/2 minutes of this song are simply rock n' roll at its purest. Axl's vocals in belting out what its like to live life like its a coma is truly unique even among G'n'R's catalogue.

B000089CJI|3.0|In a light melodic tone lead singer Benjamin Gibbard of the band Postal Service croons the phrase, \\"They will see us waving from such great heights.\\"  Yet with all their beautiful words and exotic tones, I did expect greater heights from this popular band.   <br /> The band Postal Service is made up of Gibbard, singer of the band Death Cab for Cutie, and Jimmy Tamborello from the band Dntl.   <br /> The album Give Up is a mixture of techno, pop and indie. When I first made my mom listen to it she immediately said, \\"This sounds like Depeche Mode.\\"  This album does have a Depeche Mode feel to it, with its erratic beats and melancholy lyrics, but there are some original sounds. <br /> I first heard the song \\"Such Great Heights\\" listening to an iPod on a bus.  I immediately fell in love with the strange and unique song.  I got the album as soon as possible, expecting other interesting songs.  After listening, somewhat painfully, to the entire album I was not really that impressed.  There were some intriguing songs like \\"Nothing Better\\" and \\"Recycled Air\\", but for the most part it was not on my Top Albums list. <br /> The words in this album sounded beautiful, but when you strung them all together there was not really much of a meaning.  For example in the song \\"We Will Become Silhouettes\\" it begins with, \\"I've got a cupboard with cans of food, filtered water and pictures of you and I'm not coming until this is all over.\\"   <br /> Sure these are interesting words, but why do I have to know about your cupboard?  I was expecting a little more depth.  I also felt like the singer was trying to squeeze too many words into one sentence.  This ruined the simplicity of the song and made it seem too wordy.   <br /> I do believe that this is an original band and not at all like other contemporary bands, but sometimes I wished that the band would pull out of their own style.  I would have liked to hear some songs different from their usual techno beats and scraping backgrounds.<br /> I do commend back up singer Jenny Lewis for adding colorful backgrounds.  Her feminine voice suited well with the voice of Gibbard.  I was very impressed by her voice in the song \\"Nothing Better.\\"  That song was my favorite from the whole album because it was a relief from the somewhat repetitive songs before it. <br /> This album is distinctive and absorbing, but do not go out of your way to buy it.   <br />
