B00005JOHI|5.0|Once again, I have had the pleasure of finding one of Jane Austen's classic novels brought to the big screen -- and once more I couldn't fancy myself happier.  Ah- would that there were hundreds of such renderings!<br /><br />Jane Austen's PRIDE AND PREJUDICE is amongst all in the whole vast world of literature the dearest to my heart.  Therefore, even a version that deigns tamper with a decade-old perfection serves to excite my interest.  Indeed- for I was simply ecstatic when, in 1995, A&E and the BBC collaborated to create a grand and brilliantly performed portrayal of that book.  At a length of nearly 6 hours, no aspect of this wonderful story had been neglected - and I knew that such a true commitment to the literature, combined with such passion for the tale, is a precious rarity in film. Now, years hence, that 1995 picture still resonates.  Comparisons are to be inevitable, no doubt.  I'd already been well reconciled to the fact that a two-hour version of the story, no matter how well done, could only suffer in the comparison to that A&E production.  I therefore resolved to judge this movie by its own qualities -- And what fine qualities they turned out being!  Brilliantly directed by Joe Wright, this sensual and earthy interpretation just warms my soul.<br /><br />Keira Knightley takes on the role of our heroine: Elizabeth Bennet, the 2nd oldest of the five daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Bennet (Donald Sutherland and Brenda Blethyn).  Matthew MacFadyen plays our hero: Mr. Darcy, the handsome and aloof owner of a great estate in the north of England.  The two go down the dance, waltzing through misunderstanding and mischance - wit and romance, dexterously stepping along fine lines of social propriety and distinction of class, through rejection and redemption, conjuring the many diversions of country life in Regency England. Yes, we Janeites all know the story.<br /><br />The casting herein is essentially very agreeable.  Knightly is lovely and makes for a fine Elizabeth, and the camera adores her- though when Darcy finds her appearance only \\"tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me,\\" it strikes one as rather unbelievable.  She effortlessly captures Lizzy's wry spirit and spark of humor, though I must admit I found her a little bit wanting in that quiet depth or the brilliance of mind that role calls for.<br /><br />MacFadyen's take on Darcy is more dark and brooding than actors in the past have portrayed him.  And though I enjoyed watching him, I cannot say that he did very well in expressing the changes Mr. Darcy undergoes:  I did not see an aristocrat stuffed with pride, whose passion for Elizabeth blossoms as he becomes transformed by her spirited influence.  Rather, he just seems to convey the same brooding manner all along - and his only problem appears to be that he is misunderstood.<br /><br />As for the supporting players, I think Sutherland was excellent as the bemused Mr. Bennet - and his scene with Lizzy at the end was exquisitely drawn.  Blethyn played her part very well, too - her Mrs. Bennet was every bit as laughable and endearing as Austen wrote her.  Judi Dench was wonderfully formidable as Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  The roles of Mr. Collins, Jane Bennet, Mr. Bingley and Wickham were also excellently played.<br /><br />Visually, this film is just stunning.  I've rarely, if ever, seen more exquisite scenery in a movie. The camera work is mesmerizing.  The cinematography here is certainly Oscar-worthy.  I can even forgive the overly rusticated state (complete with chickens, pigs, & all manner of livestock traipsing throughout the house) of Longbourn, the Bennet family home.  This, in fact, only serves to give charm to this beautiful and totally unique rendition of a most beloved story.dores her- though when Darcy finds her appearance only \\"tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt me,\\" it strikes one as rather unbelievable.  She effortlessly captures Lizzy's wry spirit and spark of humor, though I must admit I found her a little bit wanting in that quiet depth or the brilliance of mind that role calls for.    MacFadyen's take on Darcy is more dark and brooding than actors in the past have portrayed him.  And though I enjoyed watching him, I cannot say that he did very well in expressing the changes Mr. Darcy undergoes:  I did not see an aristocrat stuffed with pride, whose passion for Elizabeth blossoms as he becomes transformed by her spirited influence.  Rather, he just seems to convey the same brooding manner all along - and his only problem appears to be that he is misunderstood.    As for the supporting players, I think Sutherland was excellent as the bemused Mr. Bennet - and his scene with Lizzy at the end was exquisitely drawn.  Blethyn played her part very well, too - her Mrs. Bennet was every bit as laughable and endearing as Austen wrote her.  Judi Dench was wonderfully formidable as Lady Catherine de Bourgh.  The roles of Mr. Collins, Jane Bennet, Mr. Bingley and Wickham were also excellently played.    Visually, this film is just stunning.  I've rarely, if ever, seen more exquisite scenery in a movie. The camera work is mesmerizing.  The cinematography here is certainly Oscar-worthy.  I can even forgive the overly rusticated state (complete with chickens, pigs, & all manner of livestock traipsing throughout the house) of Longbourn, the Bennet family home.  This, in fact, only serves to give charm to this beautiful and totally unique rendition of a most beloved story.
0140067477|1.0|To see the behavior and mindset of Winnie the Pooh as representative of the Great Way is one thing; \\"just as he is,\\" as one might say, even though as a fictional character Pooh is a secondary representation of sentient being-in-reality.  That is to say, he exists only in our imagination as a construction of language but does not exist in the real world.  He is an illusion; yet he can serve as an imagined role model of sentience, perhaps even of enlightenment if we choose to dream him as such.<br /><br />But one should not confuse unenlightened ignorance with the sentience of non-duality no matter how childlike Pooh appears in his textual innocence.  In fact, the very comparison jumps the track from The Tao into the trap of duality just as we all do here.  I suppose we can excuse Benjamin Hoff as being \\"a finger pointing at the moon\\" despite that this allegorical attempt never gets the honey jar off its nose.<br /><br />In the initial chapters, Hoff's treatment of science lacks a clear understanding of how capable many scientists are of simply observing natural phenomena, sometimes even in a Taoist or Zen Buddhist way.  Einstein even described Buddhism, related to Taoism, as the perfect way of the scientist.  Hoff was in his early 30s when he wrote this book and I wonder what he would say about science now that he is in his 50s with more maturity and skilled practice in the true art of living simply and \\"polishing the mirror\\" of his mind.  In fact, any cognitive therapist or self-explored practitioner of meditation,  whether Taoist or otherwise, can easily recognize the fallacies of \\"gross generalization\\" and \\"minimization\\" that he dualistically applies while erroneously committing science to the pejorative categories he falsely constructs somewhere in his own fogged mirror.  As a practitioner of Zen, I found this ironic -- that he criticized science and scientists alike -- in fact he seemed to criticize all scholars and/or \\"thinkers\\" -- for being uselessly enthralled to their own narrowly labeled \\"categories\\" when in fact he was committing the very same egregiously unenlightened thinking errors with his own projected, biased, dualistic and overly simplistic categories.<br /><br />This is not to say that the scientist never misses the forest for the trees -- which seemed to be his point.  But in making it, he appeared in denial of the trees while condescendingly instructing the learned on the forest -- a mistake made by many a novice in the art of becoming effectively and truely aware.<br /><br />At first I suspected he, like so many others, was unwittingly revealing himself a phony -- a tree trimmer by trade who seemed unconsciously jealous of scientists for their degrees, \\"knowledge\\" and learning.  Certainly Emanuel Kant would be laughing his ass off.  Of Kant's five recognized epistemological methods for knowing truth -- Tenacity, Authority, Experience, Reason and Science -- the young Benjamin Hoff seems to have fallen into the traps of the lower levels of \\"knowing\\" -- Tenacity, Authority and (unfortunately, unenlightened) Experience -- without recognizing that each of the five should be integrated, each supporting the others, and used as *tools* in coming to \\"Right Thinking\\" in the Great Universal \\"Way.\\"<br /><br />Poor Pooh!  He is mistaken for one of the Holy Ones, a person of compassion and wisdom, a sentient being given to countless ways of loving kindness, a Bodhisattva, when  in fact, if Pooh were real, he is being exploited and abused in the allegory crammed cerebral cortex of Been-Jamin' Hoff in Taoist drag.<br /><br />This book is for beginners written by a beginner.  Watch out for traps!  Old Lao-tzu should have slapped this student with his staff right into the river alongside Eyore.....\\"just as he is.\\"thralled to their own narrowly labeled \\"categories\\" when in fact he was committing the very same egregiously unenlightened thinking errors with his own projected, biased, dualistic and overly simplistic categories. <br /> <br />This is not to say that the scientist never misses the forest for the trees -- which seemed to be his point.  But in making it, he appeared in denial of the trees while condescendingly instructing the learned on the forest -- a mistake made by many a novice in the art of becoming effectively and truely aware. <br /> <br />At first I suspected he, like so many others, was unwittingly revealing himself a phony -- a tree trimmer by trade who seemed unconsciously jealous of scientists for their degrees, \\"knowledge\\" and learning.  Certainly Emanuel Kant would be laughing his ass off.  Of Kant's five recognized epistemological methods for knowing truth -- Tenacity, Authority, Experience, Reason and Science -- the young Benjamin Hoff seems to have fallen into the traps of the lower levels of \\"knowing\\" -- Tenacity, Authority and (unfortunately, unenlightened) Experience -- without recognizing that each of the five should be integrated, each supporting the others, and used as *tools* in coming to \\"Right Thinking\\" in the Great Universal \\"Way.\\" <br /> <br />Poor Pooh!  He is mistaken for one of the Holy Ones, a person of compassion and wisdom, a sentient being given to countless ways of loving kindness, a Bodhisattva, when  in fact, if Pooh were real, he is being exploited and abused in the allegory crammed cerebral cortex of Been-Jamin' Hoff in Taoist drag. <br /> <br />This book is for beginners written by a beginner. B0007OCG56|5.0|This is a great story about two families with completely different ethnic backgrounds living in one house and learning how to get along and become close friends. You have the successful restaurant chef (Sandler) who was named best cook in America, and you have his newly hired maid who has a young daughter both from Mexico who moves in with Sandler's family.<br /><br />The cast and story is great with a somewhat sad ending. B00005JO04|5.0|As in the stunning \\"Traffic\\" of a few years ago, \\"Syriana\\" adopts the audacious tact of piecing together many plot strains with the intention of making some major points about the need /desperation and unending thirst for Oil. As in \\"Traffic\\" Gaghan sets up a situation in which Oil, not drugs is an obsession, a sickness really...the real stuff of life and he peoples his movie with those who support and thrive on his thesis: the C.I.A, the Arab Nations, the US oil companies. People are victimized, blown-up, tortured, brutalized and even  murdered in service of the all-mighty pursuit of black gold.<br />Writer/Director Stephen Gaghan (writer of \\"Traffic\\") has the sense though of making the proceedings global yet often times heart breakingly personal which only makes his film more persuasive, more contemporary, more like real, rather than reel, life.<br />George Clooney, bloated and bearded and not looking at all like the \\"Worlds Sexiest Man\\" plays a C.I.A. agent, Bob Barnes: a work-horse agent...one who is sent out on missions as a scapegoat, one who is not expected to succeed but time and time again completes his missions to the utter dismay of his superiors: whereas all of his contemporaries are earning raises and respect, he earns neither and in fact he is abhorred for his expertise: definitely a case of someone who gets the job done his own way and does not follow the party line: a rebel. Why? It's never really explained but it is obvious that Barnes is an outsider: a man more sinned against than sinning. And even with the extra 20 pounds, grey beard and baggy, shapeless clothes, Clooney has never been more effective: he's gruff, he's gross, he's driven but he is nonetheless a good guy...someone who always has the big picture in mind and sees and understands the forest despite the trees.<br />We, the audience view much of the action and plot of \\"Syriana\\" en Medias re: we eavesdrop on many scenes as they are unfolding rather than at their inception: a device that was used to great advantage in \\"Traffic\\" and \\"Gosford Park.\\" This process keeps us off-balance and psychologically on our toes: we pay close attention just to \\"keep up\\" and Gaghan, always the consummate storyteller punctuates his films with the rational and irrational stuff that makes us all human. There is also a dark, foreboding, mean-spirited and dangerous side to the story Gaghan is telling here: how do you differentiate the light without the dark? How do you know what is Evil without knowing the Good?<br />\\"Syriana\\" is bravura filmmaking in the best sense: universal yet coming from a personal place. In fact there is a verisimilitude about \\"Syriana\\" that is chilling and frightening: is there indeed a wolf pack of rabid Washington honchos pulling and manipulating the strings that control the world's oil supplies? Gaghan definitely has a point-of-view here and if anything his view might be too mature, too ambitious, too prescient for most of us to digest.reat advantage in \\"Traffic\\" and \\"Gosford Park.\\" This process keeps us off-balance and psychologically on our toes: we pay close attention just to \\"keep up\\" and Gaghan, always the consummate storyteller punctuates his films with the rational and irrational stuff that makes us all human. In fact there is a verisimilitude about \\"Syriana\\" that is chilling and frightening: is there indeed a wolf pack of rabid Washington honchos pulling and manipulating the strings that control the world's oil supplies? Gaghan definitely has a point-of-view here and if anything his view might be too mature, too ambitious, too prescient for most of us to digest.
B0002MG9SI|5.0|\\"Am&eacute;lie\\" is a film where you want to find the perfect word for describing its charm. There is probably such a word in French, but I would not know what it was. All I know is that quirky, enchanting, and everything I come up with in English is wholy inadequate to the task at hand. The most important thing to know is that \\"Am&eacute;lie\\" is a film where you should go see it because so many people love it, even if it requires you to not to do anything else so you can read the subtitles (some people resist such demands and--shudder--listen to dubbed versions of \\"Life is Beautiful\\" and \\"Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon\\"). I feel about this film the way I did about \\"Memento,\\" where I told people they should see it and refused to tell them anything else because it would ruin the experience (think the Heisenberg principle). However, I think the audience that would enjoy \\"Am&eacute;lie\\" is considerably wider than those who would cotton to \\"Memento\\" (which was a quirky little film).<br /><br />So, I am giving you my strongest recommendation for you to see \\"Am&eacute;lie.\\" Now, if you have not yet seen the film, please go away, because I want to talk to those who have seen the film and while I am not going to be providing what we would traditionally consider \\"spoilers,\\" you really sure come to view this film as pure and chaste as the driven snow (of which we have lots up here).<br /><br />I find it interesting that the film's French title \\"Le Fabuleux destin d'Am&eacute;lie Poulain\\" was reduced to just \\"Am&eacute;lie\\" for American consumption. Combined with the green framed portrait of actress Audrey Tautou smiling impishly as the title character, this certainly does not give viewers a real idea of what they will discover in this film. One of the chief charms of the film for me was how you had to pay attention to the details because almost everything was a clue as to future developments (the exception that proves the rule would be Blubber, whose return we patiently waited for throughout the entire film).<br /><br />Jean-Pierre Jeunet establishes the fabulous world of Am&eacute;lie Poulain in the creative prologue, which establishes what each of our cast of characters likes to do. We then begin 48 hours in which d'Am&eacute;lie's life is changed. Of course such massive developments hinge on a bottle cap fallen to the floor. Our heroine's efforts to sabotage the life of Collignon (Urbain Cancelier), the Grocer (who will never be confused with an artichoke), struck my funny bone exceedingly hard and her relationship with the Glass Man, Raymond Dufayel (Serge Merlin), was particularly nice, both their discussions about the girl with the wine glass in the Renoir painting and the old man giving her the final push to her destiny. The only question is whether Nino Quincampoix (Mathieu Kassovitz), is really good enough for our girl, but if she is smitten with a man who collects torn up and discarded photographs from photo booths around town, who are we to challenge her choice?<br /><br />The end of the fabulous 48 hours at which point our heroine finds her destiny does not offer a perfect world. Some find true bliss in love, others finally go on trips, but some still right where they started, unpublished, afflicted by imaginary illnesses, or consumed by jealousy. But as long as Am&eacute;lie lives happily ever after we are content. I pity the person who does not fall in love with this film.r /> <br />Jean-Pierre Jeunet establishes the fabulous world of Amlie Poulain in the creative prologue, which establishes what each of our cast of characters likes to do. (I'm sure most people do that.) <br /> <br />You know how people have \\"names\\"?  Like on my birth certificate it says my first name is Jeffrey. B000AA7BP2|5.0|The Buggles have their place in music history because their quirky hit \\"Video Killed the Radio Star\\" has the distinction of being the first music video shown on MTV. But their 1980 debut album \\"Age of Plastic\\" deserves to be remembered on its own terms; not just for the \\"futuristic\\" music, but because the lyrics represent a coherent critique of the world of technology as being full of potential but fraught with peril. Even a cursory look at \\"Video Killed the Radio Star\\" shows the song is offering up less than subtle ironies about the medium of pop music, not to mention the fledgling MTV. The Buggles consisted of the tandem of Geoffrey Downes on percussion/keyboards and Trevor Horn doing bass/guitar/percussion/vocals, both of who were obviously more interested in producing. That same year they produced the Yes album \\"Drama,\\" and the pair ended up joining the group and replacing Jon Anderson and Rick Wakeman.<br /><br />Pay attention to the lyrics on this album. \\"Kid Dynamo\\" is about the death of imagination in the age of mass media, a proposition that is clearly becoming more and more obvious with each year. \\"I Love You Miss Robot\\" is not kinky, despite its title, and is about the pitfalls of human dependence on technology. As for the music, it is pretty diverse. \\"\\"Video Killed the Radio Star\\" is upbeat and peppy while \\"Johnny on the Monorail\\" is the exact opposite, dark and brooding. Of course, at the time the use of electronic devices was considered cutting edge and the novelty of it all distracted from the potency of the lyrics. The Alan Parsons Project tried to do something along these lines with with 1977's \\"I Robot,\\" but that effort seems ponderous and pretentious when compared to \\"Age of Plastic.\\" I think I could make a compelling argument that this is one of the top ten, or at least top two dozen albums, from the decade (and you can go either way on that as the end of the 1970s or the start of the 1980s).

They should look back at this slice of their history and be deeply ashamed.
0393327655|2.0|I read with interest the book entitled \\"The End of Faith\\" by Sam Harris. Arguably, the key passage that sets the tone for the book can be found on page 13. It states: <br /> <br />Our situation is this: most of the people in the world believe that the Creator of the universe has written a book. We have the misfortune of having many such books on hand, each making an exclusive claim as to its infallibility. People tend to organize themselves into factions according to which of these incompatible claims they accept-rather than on the basis of language, skin color, location of birth, or any other criterion of tribalism. Each of these texts urges its readers to adopt a variety of beliefs and practices, some of which are benign, many of which are not. All are in perverse agreement on one point of fundamental importance, however: \\"respect\\" for other faiths, or for the views of unbelievers, is not an attitude that God endorses. While all faiths have been touched, here and there, by the spirit of ecumenicalism, the central tenet of every religious tradition is that all others are mere repositories of error or, at best, dangerously incomplete. Intolerance is thus intrinsic to every creed. Once a person believes-really believes-that certain ideas can lead to eternal happiness, or to its antithesis, he cannot tolerate the possibility that the people he loves might be led astray by the blandishments of unbelievers. Certainty about the next life is simply incompatible with tolerance in this one. <br /> <br />The problem is that the author, having made this statement, proceeds to practice the very thing he decries in the pages that follow. He does this, I suspect, because he is blind to his own position. No one has seen God; therefore, the assertion that He does not exist is as much a faith-based proposition as is the assertion that He does exist. What matters is what basis one provides for one's faith or non-faith-a topic of discussion for another day and one not directly addressed by the author. By conveniently excluding his own faith based world-view from the aforementioned passage, however, the author sets his own beliefs in the most favorable and reasonable light. In doing so, he is guilty of attempting to remove the speck from his neighbor's eye without paying any attention to the log in his own eye. Were he to include the world-view of those like him who neither believe in a Creator or in the after-life, he would more correctly have written the following: <br /> <br />Our situation is this: most of the people in the world believe that the Creator of the universe has or has not written a book. We have the misfortune of having many such books-including those that argue that a Creator does not exist-on hand, each making an exclusive claim as to its infallibility. People tend to organize themselves into factions according to which of these incompatible claims they accept-rather than on the basis of language, skin color, location of birth, or any other criterion of tribalism. Each of these texts urges its readers to adopt a variety of beliefs and practices, some of which are benign, many of which are not. All are in perverse agreement on one point of fundamental importance, however: \\"respect\\" for other faiths, or for the views of unbelievers, is not an attitude that God, or for those who do not believe in God, that they, endorse(s). While all faiths have been touched, here and there, by the spirit of ecumenicalism, the central tenet of every religious and anti-religious tradition is that all others are mere repositories of error or, at best, dangerously incomplete. Intolerance is thus intrinsic to every creed. Once a person believes-really believes-that certain ideas can lead to eternal, or for those that do not believe in eternity, true earthly, happiness, or to its antithesis, he cannot tolerate the possibility that the people he loves might be led astray by the blandishments of unbelievers (or believers). Certainty about the next lifeor for the unbeliever this life, is simply incompatible with tolerance in this one. <br /> <br />Ultimately, as he states in the Afterword of his book, even among atheists-those who a priori would be expected to embrace the ideas in his book-there are more than a few (based on their letters) that disagree strongly as to whether to call the author a \\"true\\" non-believer-a fact, he finds disappointing (I must say I find this surprising). Thus, I strongly suspect, that even if the authors' nave wish-that faith would disappear-were to become true, conflicts between non-believers over nuances of what constitutes true unbelief would rise to fill the vacuum. Why? Because the problem is not with the tribalisms that the author refers to. People-rich, poor, black, white, North, South-will disagree about issues-religious or not-about which they have strong opinions. Is it inconceivable to imagine that over time some of these issues could become so divisive that they could lead to armed conflict. History tells us that men have fought over and died over the silliest of issues. This is an unmistakable reality:  Humankind will always have issues that divide, some for which they will be prepared to lay down their lives. What the author hopes to do is to replace current dichotomies (by no means homogenous) such as the Christian worldview vs. other worldviews, the Islamic worldview vs. other worldviews, the atheistic worldview vs. other worldviews with a new singularity, i.e. atheism. Yet if the goal is to secure the peace by promoting one viewpoint, surely we can achieve the same goal simply by replacing all these dichotomies with any singularity. Why not choose Christianity, Islam or some other faith as the common truth-then we would all get along. But would such a peace last? Wouldn't new ideologies, beliefs and theories, arise even within the sphere of anti-faith (similar to Sunni-Shiite groupings in Islam, or Catholic-protestant groupings in Christianity) to replace those recently banished. It appears to me, based on recent history, that they most certainly would. Consequently, the real solution seems to lie in how we resolve extant conflicts. To that end, I would rather choose the Man who said \\"forgive your enemies\\" \\"do good to those who hurt you\\", \\"if slapped turn the other cheek\\", the one who ultimately \\"walked the talk\\" by dying on the cross-all the while praying for his executioners. For me, that example is a far better prescription for peace than the proposal put forth by the author that people can and should be convinced to transfer their allegiances from faith to anti-faith.

B000B5253E|4.0|WOW! The ethereal power behind this band is mind-boggling. As a guitarist, I am blown away by the ability of the guitarists, Matt and Padge! I was first exposed to BFMV in July, when I stumbled upon the Trustkill Records \\"Takeover\\" sampler at a Hot Topic in St.Petersburg, Florida. It was love at first listen. I was quick to purchase the album from the band's site when it was released in the UK and Asia on October 3rd. It took about a month to reach me, but that is neither here nor there. The album is chock full of hits. The guitar solos are reminiscent of the late great Dimebag Darrell, as well as the reigning gods of heavy metal, Zakk Wylde and Kerry King. I recommend this album to any metalhead, as well as some of the alright emo losers. Yes, this album has a great deal of emo influence, though the talent of the guitarists outdoes any emo band on their best day.The vocals are perfect for the band's sound! Check it out if you do not wish to wait until February 16, 2006.
1594200653|4.0|For some reason the modern history of Europe doesn't seem to catch the attention of many writers so I was glad when I saw this book. Most of what I know about Europe in this century revolves around either of the two world wars. I think Judt does a great job of filling in the blanks. I especially like that this history concerns all of Europe - so many books focus on France or Germany or England and leave out the likes of Czechoslovakia or other `lesser' countries. The book is long and not always easy reading as would be expected with a book of this breadth. Judt does an admirable job with such a complex and detailed topic. I think that the history of Europe as a block is just beginning and this is a great foundation to understanding how they got where they are and where they are going.
B0000041Z6|5.0|So many Mahler performances, both in concert and on record, are mannered to the extent that one senses a conductor trying to convey the impression that it is his personal suffering, not the composer's vision, which is producing such beautiful music. <br />Not Solti's.  He and his incredibly virtuosic orchestra let Mahler do the talking.  The 5th, 6th and 7th especially lend themselves to Solti's approach, while the 8th benefits from his <br />long, successful career in the pit.  Though Karajan, Walter, Guilini and others have recorded great 9ths, I defy anyone to find a better played one than this.  Solti gives us the orchestral tours de force that are the Mahler Symphonies and which, I believe, explain why \\"my(his)time will(has) come.\\"
0060555661|4.0|I decided to read this book after reading a biography of Warren Buffet. I learned that Buffet was a student of Graham, so I was curious to learn more. I am not an expert, merely an average investor with basic knowledge. I have no plans to devise or follow an advanced investment strategy, and can't comment on whether you would be helped by reading this book if that is your goal. I did find it informative about one of the many schools of thought in the world of stock investing. It was worth reading for that reason. However, don't get this book if you want something that will be a breeze to read.  If you have a basic background and are ready for something more technical, give this book a try.  <br /> <br />It helps to be aware that the text consists partly of Graham's original early-twentieth century writings, with updates and commentary by a modern investment expert. Add loads of footnotes and citations, and you have more of a college text  than a popularized investment guide to tote to the beach.  <br /> <br />

0393327655|2.0|We can expect people of faith to take exception to a book called \\"The End of Faith,\\" as so many of the reviews below testify. That is not a surprise.    What is surprising is to find people who basically agree with Harris' position also expressing opposition and disappointment to this book. I add myself to that list. The central points Harris is making -- that it's about time religious faith be divested of its respectability and criticized squarely for what it is; and that religious faith in an era of nuclear and biological weapons may well kill us all -- these points are worth making. It's just that Harris does not make them very well.    The historical overviews of the inquisition and other Christian excesses are weak, superficial, and don't add much to the debate.  His chapter on Islam is close to risible. We get arguments like this: the problems of the Middle East have nothing to do with poverty, oppression, and tyrannical governments because, well, lots of other people endure these conditions and don't blow themselves up on buses. Ergo, only the tenets of Islamic faith can explain such atrocities. When you look at those tenets, you find the basis for Islamic cultural retardation. So, concludes Harris, Muslims are throwbacks to the 14th century.    This is laughably superficial. Robert Pape (in his book \\"Dying to Win\\") has demonstrated beyond a shadow of doubt, and from masses of carefully assembled data, that suicide terrorism is a strategic, military choice, not a product of religious fanaticism. No doubt, religious fanaticism enables suicide terrorism, but it is not its prime cause. Further, to answer Harris' argument, it could be pointed out that lots of Muslims live all over the world and don't blow themselves up. They don't do it in Qatar, or in Dubai or in the United Arab Emirates -- all affluent (and relatively open) societies. They don't do it in Syria or Jordan (at least, homegrown suicide bombers don't). They're all Muslims there, aren't they? What unites campaigns of suicide terrorism is *not* Islam. It's political conflict. It is fundamentally dishonest to argue otherwise.    The fundamental problem here is a failure to appreciate complexity. Harris argues monolaterally, offering a single, umbrella reason for all the problems of the Middle East. But those problems are horribly complex. Judaism, for instance, is not a religious faith. It's an ethnic identity, a nationalism, a way of life, and a faith all rolled into one. It's likely that a nexus of such factors stands behind the current mess, in which religious faith plays its part, no doubt. But it can't do all the heavy lifting for the woes of Middle East. There's more to it than that.    After these disappointing chapters, comes some seriously dubious argumentation: US-inflicted \\"collateral damage,\\" no matter how many are maimed or killed, cannot be equated morally with Al Qaeda depredations, since the intentions of the US are good. So, it seems, consequences needn't delay us long.  OK. I disagree, but Harris is entitled to his (incorrect) position. But then comes this: if we are prepared to accept inflicting civilian casualties as \\"collateral damage\\" in our wars, we have no moral basis to object to torture, which we should also accept, even if the victims might be innocent.    Wait a minute ... what happened to the cleansing effect of good intentions? Adopting Harris' position for the sake of argument, aren't we in very different moral territory inadvertently inflicting \\"collateral damage\\" than we are purposely strapping some poor bugger to a table and attaching electrodes to his genitals? Perhaps, if in doing the strapping, you have good intentions, then it's OK. This is an argument Josef Mengele would be comfortable with.    When we get to the end, there comes a crashing disappointment and a terrible realization. Harris is into meditation. He likes his Eastern mysticism. He attempts to justify the \\"rationality\\" of such mystical exploration, but things getvery ropey. He's not a dualist, but he's not a physicalist either. I think it highly dubious to put the mystical speculations of eastern yogi alongside the corpus of scientific exploration and claim that they are two sides of a single coin. Just put the test of achievement to each one: what, exactly, have millennia of mystical musings achieved, as opposed to a few centuries of the scientific enterprise? How have the mystics helped humanity? Scientific medicine has, in a single century, doubled the average life expectancy of the developed world. Given the political and economic will (so tragically lacking today), we could easily extend this benefit across the globe. Science has, literally, given us the gift of decades more life. What gift can the Krishnas claim to have bestowed in comparison? Getting in touch with the inner eye? I'll take the decades, please.    As one reads this section, one starts to suspect that Harris is not really about slamming faith-based claptrap because it's claptrap, but rather that he slams it because it's not the claptrap he approves of. He has his own favorite mumbo-jumbo (some of it quoted approvingly, when it makes no sense to the uninitiate).    It's a horrible moment.    The fundamental points Harris makes about faith need to be made. This isn't the book to make them.
B00005JNZJ|3.0|First off, I have only seen segments of the Liquid Television \\"Aeon Flux\\" animated episodes back in the 90's, so I'm not qualified to give an in-depth comparison to this movie. Fanboys of the original series are going to throw popcorn at the screen, and are advised to skip it. A large part of this movie relies on her sex appeal and it never apologizes for it. But if you're trying to save some money and want to limit your movie watching, give this one a pass and wait for \\"The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe\\" or \\"King Kong,\\" which will surely be light years better.
1400032717|5.0|As a mother with an autistic spectrum child, I absolutely loved this book, and cried at the ending and the protagonist's (Christopher Boone's) optimism.<br /><br />I have long since passed the stage of wanting my child to be \\"normal\\" (and in fact have strong thoughts about what \\"normal\\" means, but that is another story). Now, however, my deepest hope is that my child adapts to his unique challenges, and leverages his unique strengths, to make a meaningful life for himself.<br /><br />Christopher Boone does this in spades, hence my tears at the ending.<br /><br />The book's depiction of autism/aspergers syndrome rings extraordinarily true, based on the many children I know with autism (including my own).  This is not to say I know anyone who is precisely like Christopher - autism is a spectrum disorder, the symptoms and severity vary tremendously from person to person.<br /><br />The story line itself is quite interesting, Christopher tries to solve the mystery of a dog's murder, and in doing so, uncovers secrets in his past.  He also, through sheer power of reason and will, forces himself out of his comfort zone (a BIG deal for an autistic person) in order to solve the mystery.  This was, for me, profoundly moving.<br /><br />There is also a fascinating disconnect between the way Christopher responds to what he discovers, and the way the READER responds.  We are much more aware of the pain and unhappiness surrounding his situation than he is.<br /><br />As someone who worries a bit about what the future holds for my son, I have to admit to being pleasantly surprised about the warm reception this book has received from the general public.  I find that incredibly encouraging, that so many others see and respond to the dignity and humanity in Christopher, instead of writing him off as a freak.  Thank you, Mark Haddon.

0440180295|5.0|Some people stay away from books that receive a lot of critical praise.  I'm not sure why, but if I had to guess I'd say they fear that it may be difficult to read or dry.<br /><br />You can't say either of those things about Vonnegut.  This book is the perfect introduction if you're not familiar with the author.  Not only is it humorous, but it's also concise and easy to read.  It's a book about war, but it never gets preachy.<br /><br />The plot deals with one character--Billy Pilgrim--who served in WWII.  When he comes home, he become an eye doctor and later claims to have been abducted by aliens.  The plot sounds a little crazy and hard to follow, but it all makes sense once you get into the book.<br /><br />Vonnegut and Hemingway share a trait that most readers should enjoy:  they are both precise and to the point.  There are very few wasted words and you don't get bogged down with long descriptions or flowery prose.  That's not to say that the story isn't well-written.  It's just written in a manner that most people will appreciate.
B000001FS6|3.0|U2 had been steaming forward with such tremendous momentum that they were bound to eventually miss a beat. With the near-unanimous critical and commercial success that was \\"The Joshua Tree,\\" they decided to try to document themselves and their tour. For the first time, their reach exceeded their grasp, as \\"Rattle and Hum\\" exposed a band willing to show all the warts. But those warts made for a pretentious film and a so-so album. This was the holding pattern that stayed in place till the band gathered their wits and reinvented themselves with \\"Achtung, Baby.\\"<br /><br />That is not to say that the soundtrack to \\"Rattle And Hum\\" is without merit. Indeed, \\"All I Want,\\" \\"Desire\\" and \\"When Love Comes To Town\\" are stunning in the way U2 absorbs American Music and spins it through their own portal. BB King on \\"When Love Comes To Town\\" is a particular highlight. But the choice of including Jimi Hendrix' \\"Star Spangled Banner\\" seems like an attempt to attach their genius by association, and with a band as brilliant as U2, comes off as arrogant at worst/misguided at best. Same with the not-all-too-inspired covers of \\"All Along The Watchtower\\" and \\"Helter Skelter\\" (even though Bono recently was quoted in Rolling Stone that he worships the White Album).<br /><br />The live tracks are also haphazard. \\"Bullet The Blue Sky\\" (minus the Hendrix miscue) is stunning, and the gospel version of \\"I Still Haven't Found What I'm Looking For\\" is definitive. But it also means you sit through a rough version of \\"Silver and Gold\\" with Bono taunting the crowd (\\"Am I bugging you? I don't mean to bug ya\\"). For a live CD, you're better served by \\"Under A Blood Red Sky.\\" So get this if you have to have it all, since the main three studio tracks appear on U2's greatest hits sets. I can't dismiss it, simply because U2 are probably the band that came out of the 80's that will have an enduring legacy, but there are better places to go if you're looking for a primer than \\"Rattle And Hum.\\"
0767903862|3.0|This is a very well written, very funny series of anecdotical comments regarding Australia. B00005JO1P|5.0|\\"Walk the Line\\" tells the story of country music star Johnny Cash from his early days until his marriage to June Carter in 1968. Joaquin Phoenix is terrific, capturing the mannerisms and singing style of Cash as well as any actor possibly could. Reese Witherspoon does a fine job as well. Her June Carter is a spunky, intelligent young woman who finally manages to provide Cash the solid grounding that he so desperately needs. <br /> <br />I especially enjoyed the scenes of Johnny's childhood. The movie really captures the simplicity and hardship of life in rural Arkansas at this time. This boyhood period also includes the tragic death of his older brother, Jack. Johnny's guilt over not being there to save his brother from a sawmill accident provides the psychological background for much of what happens later in the movie.   <br /> <br />The film's most prominent musical focus is on Cash's early days as a rockabilly artist, hanging out with Elvis, Jerry Lee Lewis and the boys. It's worth remembering that Johnny was a rebellious, young rocker before later returning to his country music roots. It was during these days that he first met and fell in love with June Carter. But she was newly divorced and he was still unhappily married. So they remained \\"only friends\\" for many years before admitting their passion and love for one another. But by this time Cash had become addicted to pharmaceutical drugs and June realized a successful marriage would be impossible. Finally, with the help of June and the Carter family, Johnny is able to quit taking the pills and get his life back on track. But, the now twice divorced, June is reluctant to marry again despite Johnny's desperate pleading. I found the ending, where June finally accepts Johnny's marriage proposal on stage to be improbable and a bit cheesy. But if that is how it really happened then that's how it had to be filmed. <br /> <br />Overall \\"Walk the Line\\" is a terrific film about two extraordinary people. The music is great and if you are a Johnny Cash fan you will love listening to it. Highly recommended.    <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />

Buy the cd, see him in person, seeand hear Ray for yourself, he won't disappoint.

B000021XS0|4.0|Before I begin to go in depth about this album and my opionions about it, I must first explain that first and foremost, I am a fan of music - not just the prog scene, and I am a big fan of Dream Theater. With that being said, this is Dream Theater's most complicated and difficult album to date. That's not an insult to the album, if anything it is a compliment, but it's also a fair warning to you casual listeners out there. <br /> <br />From the distant perspective, this is not a work that should be approached from the stance of it being an album: it's really one song, a suite divided amongst 12 tracks for easier accessability. It's also played out a lot like an epic poem, a story that's sequencial to the \\"Images and Words\\" epic \\"Metropolis Part I: The Miracle and the Sleeper\\". Sung in first person perspective, you experience the realization of Nicholas, who in dreams experiences the life of a little girl who was murdered many years ago. The story is complex and can be difficult to follow, but after a few listens they will make a lot more sense.  <br /> <br />It's not the lyrics that truly define what this album is though, it's the music. In many ways, the lyrics just play as a backdrop to a grandiose masterwork that John Petrucci, Mike Portnoy, John Myung, and newcomer Jordan Rudess have composed. In fact, in many ways this album feels as though it could be played as a complete instrumental. It's because of that this album tends to drag during the middle, as lead singer James Labrie seems to try to do too much, not staying within the context of the music. This flaw can be easily overlooked though, as this is a refreshing Dream Theater experience that will fondly be recalled as one of the greatest truly progressive albums of all time.

B000002KHH|5.0|That's the main chorus line of the song, \\"Paranoid\\", if you're wondering what the title of this reveiw is about.  What can I say.  Led Zeppelin may have invented heavy metal but Black Sabbath took it to new levels.  Inserting lyrics and story lines regarding war, God, Satan, insanity, Armaggedon, and yes even drug abuse, Sabbath redefined what hard rock was about.  They proved that on the monolithic release, their self titled debut, \\"Black Sabbath\\".  But they didn't fully perfect their style untill they released this album. <br /> <br />The album never lets up during its forty minute duration.  It opens with the metal epic, \\"War Pigs\\", a creepy tale of how the governments of countries at war are punished by God.  Containing classic guitar work by Tony Iommi, this has become a staple of metal music.  \\"Paranoid\\", is a faster almost punk like track devoted to only one thing; insanity.  With its classic guitar riff and unforgettable lyrics you really feel as if your insane by the time the song is over.  \\"Planet Caravan\\", is a very moody almost beautiful ballad. certainly the quite point of the album.  Things then do a 180 with the track, \\"Iron Man\\".  Beginning with a slow string of guitar bends and then leading into the most recognizable guitar riff in the history of rock music.  Another strange song about a man who takes revenge on those he once saved the lives of.  They then turne him into some kind of robot hence the name iron man.  Then again the lyrics could just be utter nonsense with no meaning at all. <br /> <br />\\"Electric Funeral\\", is a nice, warm, child friendly tale about nuclear fallout and people who have been burned alive by radiation.  Once again, God comes to earth to set things right. <br />\\"Hand Of Doom\\", is a song about drug addiction, most notably heroin.  \\"Rat Salad\\", is a short instrumental featuring some incredible drum work by Bill Ward.  \\"Faries Wear Boots\\", is a comical song about a man who sees faries and dwarves while high on God knows what.<br /> <br />Now Metallica may have later took this formula and perfected even more so than Sabbath did but the thing that matters is that Sabbath started it all.  A landmark release in every way imaginable.  If you don't own this album then you really are paranoid!
B000002KET|5.0|This was one of my first introductions to Sabbath, often put off by the overtly `dark' vibes that seemed somewhat clich&eacute;d, I never really gave Sabbath much of a listen, that is until this album completely crushed my ignorance. This album is undeniably one of Sabbath's best, the sound is perfect and everything you'd want from a `classic' metal album. At times the band venture into a more synth-heavy sound, something a little more experimental than previous releases, but the relentless Iommi riffing and piercing screams of Ozzy are still there, and as good as ever.<br /><br />As mentioned above Sabbath ventured into new ground with a higher emphasis on synthesizers, for me it's hit and miss. The two songs that feature the synth most heavily are the dreamy `Who Are You?' and the fine closer `Spiral Architect', when listening to `Who Are You?' today, the synths are somewhat dated and become monotonous, while probably being rather cutting edge and `spaced-out' sounding in its day, its nothing special now, thus making the only weak song on the album. In sharp contradiction the use of synths on `Spiral Architect' is far subtler, instead of becoming the main feature it simply adds to the lush guitar and vocal melodies, the dreamy atmosphere really works here and provides a fine ending to the album.<br /><br />The rest of the music, except the short instrumental `Fluff', is pure guitar driven Sabbath at it's best. The title track opener is amongst their best work, the riffs are punishing while retaining a wondrous `groove' sense. `A National Acrobat' is another fine piece, much like the title track the song is split into two main sections, the latter section being a fine groove laden expedition of Iommi's distinguished riffing. `Sabbra Cadabra' is an instant winner, and deservedly one of Sabbath's most recognised pieces. My personal favourite on the album comes in `Killing Yourself To Live', the numerous riffs are all utterly compelling, especially the sinister chorus melody that accompanies Ozzy's wild screams. Once again the song takes a different direction creating another two section structure, the second part to `Killing Yourself To Live' is the perfect example of what groove laden metal should sound like, and what many of the modern era `stoner' bands try to re-create.<br /><br />This is a must have for any fan of hard rock/metal, Sabbath are undeniable metal heroes, and this album showcases their full armoury.elody that accompanies Ozzy's wild screams. Once again the song takes a different direction creating another two section structure, the second part to `Killing Yourself To Live' is the perfect example of what groove laden metal should sound like, and what many of the modern era `stoner' bands try to re-create.  <br /> <br />This is a must have for any fan of hard rock/metal, Sabbath are undeniable metal heroes, and this album showcases their full armoury. <br />

And that's exactly why I never ventured to purchase her albums. I see comparisons to Miss Holiday and I instantly think of Lisa Ekdahl who was supposed to be Sweden's answer to Billie Holiday. NOT! (To her credit, \\"Now or Never\\" was decent, but I digress....) <br /> <br />I grabbed this album on impulse, wondering all the while if I had lost all my senses. Let me tell you, I was dead wrong about Madeline Peyroux. She is the real deal. Yes, there are similarities to Billie and hints of Ella, but she is nevertheless her own unique singer. And what a singer she is. Her voice is as smooth and rich as aged single-malt scotch over ice. Her phrasing is dead-on. There isn't a single clunker on the album. Needless to say, I'm eating crow and ordering her debut album, coughing up feathers all the while.
0743454537|5.0|This book is beautifully written.  The charcters feel like people you know, that is what makes the rest so devistating. <br /> <br />The plot of this book reads like a hypothetical from a bioethics class, sister who was designed to be a genetic match for an ill sister wants to make her own decision about donating a kidney.  That alone would cause you to think.   <br /> <br />The beauty of this book is that it makes you both think and feel, to deal with the reality that these decision are about people, not hypotheticals. <br /> <br />Read it, no matter what you might think going in, this book will  challange that idea.
B00008S2VG|2.0|I don't really the rating system here, but I couldn't have given American Life a 3 when I gave Music a 4 and Erotica a 3 also. Those two albums go in a nice direction, whereas American Life is one very rocky ride. It seems that this is one of her most reviewed albums on here and I can certainly see why. Let me say that I love Madonna; I'm a fanatic. But I also know good music, and overall, this album is her weakest in the whole catalog. The thing about American Life is that is very listenable, but you are kind of left wanting more and thinking of ways the songs could have been better. The disc seems to be part of some kind of spiritual awakening trilogy, where Madonna discusses her new life as mom, heroine, and refugee from the material world. It worked best on 'Ray of Light', it was tolerable on 'Music', here it's just tired. \\"Nobody Knows Me\\" kicks a killer groove, but as far as the message goes, Madonna isn't telling us anything we didn't already know. \\"I don't watch TV/I don't waste my time reading magazines,\\" she proclaims. Ambiguity goes a long way here, on other songs such as \\"Intervention\\"; what is she saving her baby from? It might be a better song if there was something happening here!Yeah that's nice honey, but what else you got in your bag of tricks? Also a problem with this song and many others is Madonna's increasing problem with lyrics. On \\"Nobody\\" she says, \\"I'm not that kind of guy/sometimes I feel shy...\\" Ick. And what about that awkward rap in \\"American Life\\". I'm not sure if she meant it to be serious or cute, but when you rap about soy lattes and mini coopers, Ritchie we have a problem! In the \\"Oh Father\\"-esque \\"Mother and Father\\", she calls her father a \\"jerk\\" for having to go to \\"work\\" and after her mother's death all she did was \\"sit and cry...cry and cry and cry all day until the neighbors went away\\". Now I like the thumping digi-disco beats in the song, but how can we take it seriously with lyrics like those? Or are all the Madonna fans just supposed to keep dancing to keep from rolling on the floor laughing? Trust me, fellow Madonna fans, I'm not making fun of her by any means, but I think anyone can see that on 'American Life' there is much room for improvement. So the title of the album is 'American Life' and judging by its content its Madonna's american life and not ours. Where 'Erotica' was hardly about sex at all, 'American Life' is not about the state of the world, but the state of Madonna's world. The only real statement she is making is with her military get up in the artwork and the controversial \\"American Life\\" video. Where is a song about her frustration over the Bush administration? Where is there talk about anything other than the downside to celebrity living? Whatever Madonna was striving for, we're not sure. It is a rather intriguing album once you get past all of that. In between all the kinks and bugs, there is pretty good production in \\"Hollywood\\", where Madonna warns that there is a dark side to such a seemingly perfect place. She never tells us why it's bad, but we listen just the same and get into the groove. There's \\"I'm So Stupid\\" that snatches \\"Everybody's looking for something\\" from the Eurthymic's \\"Sweet Dreams\\". There is an odd charm to this song, however immature it may seem. A lot of the songs hardly seem like the work of someone Madonna's age, but for a woman who uses various aspects of culture to launch a \\"new statement\\" in her always anticpated releases, songwriting often plays second fiddle. But as we have seen in the past on such records as 'Ray of Light' and 'Like a Prayer', Madonna has the ability to counter the pop trend of the moment with meaningful writing. For Madonna fans and fans of music alike, we all appreciate an artist for different reasons. I don't base my love for Madonna strictly on songwriting. It's the whole package. Hr transformations, her business savvy, and her boldness have all played a part in it for me over the years. But on 'American Life' I can't ignore what i hear. Thats not to say I hate the album and never play it. It takes a spin more often than most of my CDs do and it has it;s own niche in my Madonna collection. It just stands in the shadows of albums just like 'Ray' and 'Prayer'. What is consistent about the album, is that is self-referential. \\"Mother and Father\\" is a sort of continuation of \\"Oh Father\\" without really accomplishing much. \\"Nothing Fails\\" is one of my favorite songs on the disc, but its religious theme and blurred line between sex and God is nowhere near as sensual and beautiful as it's older sister \\"Like a Prayer\\", which also contains a choir. The big standout is \\"Die Another Day\\" from the latest Bond flick, and although rabid fans already had the single, most would admit they were relieved when they learned it was part of the spotty track list. It's orchestral/techno wave is slick, fun and clever. It's one of the few songs on here that showcase what Madonna is best at: juxtaposing between fiery dance goddess and awakened den mother. Here she sounds like an adult, doing battle against the world and herself. It's triumphant as it plays against songs where she falls short of her true talent. Whatever that talent is, it's Madonna's secret formula. It's worked for decades, but this time the package is missing some weight.

B00005JNBQ|2.0|For nearly a year, I've had to endure siblings and friends quoting this movie and breaking into uncontrollable fits of laughter, so I finally decided I had to see it too so that I might laugh along. From the opening scene, things looked mildly promising. Napolean, the nerdiest, sleepiest-looking high-schooler you've ever seen hops on a school bus where another kid asks, \\"Napolean, what are you going to do today?\\" Napolean replies \\"Whatever I feel like -- GOSH!\\" with a little jerk of his head. Then he pulls a plastic figurine from his pocket, ties a string around its neck, and lowers it out of the window, letting it drag along the ground behind the bus. All right, I thought, this is going to be one of those screwy comedies full of eccentric characters who do random things. I was prepared for that, but I wasn't prepared for the 90-minute borefest that ensued. With no real plot to speak of, and characters that just aren't that likeable or interesting, I found myself longing for the movie to be over only a few minutes into it. I stuck it through in the hopes that it would improve, but no such luck. As far as comedes go, the humor in this one is quite subtle, and consistent in style throughout. If you like the first ten minutes, you'll probably enjoy the rest of the movie. If after ten minutes you find it isn't your cup of tea, stop there--it doesn't get any better. <br /> <br />I was tempted to give only one star, but I felt like being a little generous, perhaps because after suffering through this movie, I finally can understand references to it (those \\"Vote for Pedro\\" bumper stickers and tee-shirts, my family's quotes, and Heder's recent appearance on Saturday Night Live, which was quite funny after seeing this film). Apparently, this is a film you either love or hate. I can't stand it. If you have not yet seen this move, I'd recommend borrowing it or renting it before buying.

0385486804|4.0|After recently reading book 1 of Cervante's 'Don Quixote', and just today finishing Krakauer's 'Into the Wild', I am struck by the similarities between the real-life Chris McCandless and the fictional Don Quioxte.  Both read into their their favorite books too much and in their minds (and daily lives) the fiction becomes a reality.  Quixote has his knight-errants, McCandless has his isolationists.  Both are in a constant search for 'adventure'.  Both assume pseudonyms.  Both are repeatedly warned that their actions are irrational. Sancho Panza tells Quixote the windmills are not monsters.  Jim Gallien tells McCandless his provisions are too little to survive.  There are many more examples from both.  But, alas, both of the 'adventure seekers' ignore the warnings and plunge headlong into their fantasies.  Quixote gets beat up and bruised every time, McCandless ends up dead.  Sadly, both shun their families and keep them in a constant state of sadness and hope for a return.   <br />    <br />It's also important to note that both characters were not stupid people.  Don Quixote repeatedly amazes people with his penetrating insights and deep levels of understanding when talking of everyday, real life issues and enjoys the respect of his community.  McCandless is a brilliant college gradute that also enjoys the respect of his community.   <br />   <br />I think McCandless's life of journies was not bad (at least, unlike Quixote, he didn't physically hurt others), it's just that he was too stubborn to learn the proper way to lead a healthy existence in the wild.  Krakauer points out that McCandless survived for several months on his own and essentially made only one, albeit fatal, mistake.  I pose this question: what would have happened had he not found the bus?  He didn't know there a bus out there to live in.  His journal entry the day he finds the bus states \\"MAGIC BUS!\\"  He didn't have a tent, warm enough clothes, a grill to cook his meat on.  All that was in the 'magic bus'.  <br />    <br />As for a review of the book, I give it four stars because it definately is a page turner and it sucks you in whether you like the protaganist or not (I do like McCandless, he seemed like an very nice person to know--he was just too stubborn...).  I do recommend just checking it out from the library--it's a quick read.  I'm a slow reader (it took me a month and a half to get through book 1 of Don Quixote!), but I checked this book out at 5pm yesterday and returned it this morning.  It only gets four stars because the book reads just like the magazine article--you could just read that if you're only interested in McCandless.  Read the book to get Krakauer's fascinating tale of his own attempt at climbing the frightful 'Devil's Thumb' near Petersburg, Alaska.
B000002J09|4.0|Led Zeppelin IV (ZOSO) was released in 1971 and is Led Zeppelin fourth studio album.    Led Zeppelin established Themselves as champions of Rock N' Roll in the late 60s/early 70s. Their first two albums were groundbreaking for Rock music. There were many other bands in that time, but it was Led Zeppelin who played raw, furious blues-rock that shook the world. After controversial \\"III\\" the band released album that is regarded as their finest hour and creative peak.     My personal opinion for ZOSO is that this album is solid, but it's not perfect. I would not call it Led Zeppelin best by any means. Even though there are great classics here, a couple of songs are just decent.     The album opens with a hardrock note - Black Dog, excellent rocker, delivers amazing riffing from Jimmy Page and immortal lines from Robert Plant \\"Hey Hey Mum, said the way You move...\\". Easily one of Led Zeppelin finest moments. Rock N' Roll follows next, the title describes perfectly what the song is about. Loud and fast, though not as strong as Black Dog, it's another Zepp classic. Here we have a change of pace: Battle of Evermore is soft, mellow and experimental acoustic tune that works pretty well, but this song is nothing special. Not a filler, but a decent one.  Stairway To Heaven - Do I really need to explain on this one? Ah, I will say something on this one actually. Easily one of the best songs ever written. Pure magic. Haunting acoustic melodies played by Page are amazing. Plant shines on his vocal performance here. The song builds up, and at the end it is finished by piercing and dramatic guitar riffing with crying Plant vocals. Absolutely awesome piece.   Unfortunately, the album slips here. Awful Misty Mountain Hop is next. I don't know exactly why, but I hate this song. It is repetitive, and overall it sounds silly. Lame.  It gets a bit better on Four Sticks - this song is an experimental tune, and it's basically about drumming (John Bonham uses four sticks on the drums). It'sinteresting, but overall nothing special. Going To California is strong point of the album. Sweet and beautiful acoustic ballad. Charming guitar work and incredible vocal performance.   Everybody seems to praise When The Leeve Breaks so much - I always tried to understand what's so amazing about this song - for me it's just endless, repetetive blues. Nothing great definately, loooooong as hell, and not so interesting.     Overall - Overrated album, but still great. Though there are couple of decent tunes here, the rest is worth checking out. Recommended.

0517548232|3.0|Being an Economic and Philosophy student both, I found this book intriguing.  I set out to kill two birds with one stone, however found myself rather surprised. While it applied to economics and taught and reiterated my class at school, it really drove home the ideas of philosophy. This book related to my philosphy and critical thinking class, because Henry Hazlitt makes a claim in the first chapter of the book and the following twenty five are the lesson being applied in economic terms.  He makes sure you understand and can apply his claim/lesson to the real world, all while showing you the faults many economist make.  All of his supporting stories are relevant and make since, they are all clearly written making sure his own view is shown, and they are complete, taking into consideration all points of view.     <br /> The book points out the fallacies of claims made by economists, and in doing so teaches you economics, and how to think correctly as one. He does not, however, take a typical approach to this economics thing.  He throws you right in and teaches you the lesson right away.  His lesson asks you to remember one thing.  <br />  \\"The art of economics consists in looking not merely at the immediate but at the longer effects of any act of policy; it consists in tracing the consequences of that policy not merely for one group but for all groups.\\"  <br /> This claim was something I was taught in my economics class, and I gladly related to it while reading. Some of my favorite chapters had to do with the broken window fallacy, minimum wage laws, and the mirage on inflation. All breaking down the faults of our government and the faults in our reasoning. Every chapter in the book brings home the main message of looking past the up front realities. To look outside of the box.    <br /> I felt Hazlitt took on a fair view of the people.  He stated many times,\\"if we have trained ourselves to look beyond immediate to secondary consequences.\\"  I think this applies to many people. The word if leaves it open, covering all individuals.  He also puts in his lesson, \\"not merely for one group but for all groups.\\" He does look at it for all groups, mentioning all people who would feel the effects of whatever program is put into place.  <br /> I honestly liked reading the book. If you are an economics or philosophy major, both of which I am not, the book is worth more closer review.  I would recommend it to anyone looking to find faults or learn economics.

B000002JS6|5.0|The sad and sudden death of AC/DC frontman Bon Scott would leave the band in a vary precarious situation.  With their popularity on the rise, coming of the mega-successful Highway To Hell, what were they going to do now that their lead singer had drank himself to death? (Hear Ozzy's Suicide Solution as an ode to Scott).  Well...they went out and picked up a geezer off the streets that they'd seen performing in the pubs by the name of Brian Johnson.  Thus Back In Black is born.  The quintessential AC/DC album.  On the list of biggest selling albums of all time and for one specific reason: it rocks!  Are the songs juvenile and chock-full of teeny-bopper sexual innuendos?  Hell, yes!  But this is metal in 1980 and the AC/DC boyz weren't exactly Ivy League material.  There are gems here, staples of modern rock.  Hells Bells which is used at every sporting event in America at one time or another.  Back In Black, You Shook Me All Night Long, Shoot To Thrill, & More.  This is the s*it!<br /><br />Dig it!

0684824906|5.0|<br />Who would have thought that a book about dear old Abe would have relevance today?  Talk about history repeating itself. Unfortunately. What was the major political issue of the time? The same theme that present day Civil War buffs argue about- ie. was the fight about union or slavery? There was not much agreement in the camps and Lincoln's greatness was to keep both on his side. Lincoln's political alacrity is an aspect few people realized- then or now. My favorite vignette: Abe at age 6 or 7 listening to adult stories around the fireplace and then translating them into kid-speak so that he could take the stump and charm the neighborhood. This skill served him well all his political life. Lincoln was also very patient always with a constructive motive. Example, his Secretary of the Treasury-Chase entertained the strong desires of becoming President and inflicted upon Lincoln often severe open criticisms to the public. These criticisms were vicious and many times exaggerated only to grace a better appearance for Chase. This was consummated with Chase resignation delivered on four separate occasions with all four times Chase assuming he was too important to be allowed to leave Lincoln's cabinet. But finally his welcome was outgrown its usefulness and Lincoln unexpectantly allowed him to leave the administration. The first 200-300 pages of the book are the strongest and most engrossing; once we get past the Emancipation Proclamation there's much less to mine that hasn't been dealt with before. Still, it's a wonderful book and required reading for any Lincoln buff. <br />
0062502182|4.0|Coehlo's \\"The Alchemist\\" has achieved the well deserved status of being categorized as an \\"important\\" novel to those in the literary know.  The book is short, simple and endearing and it undoubtedly one of the leaders in the \\"inspiration\\" genre.  It's simplicity is its strength and the story would serve in probably any medium including the lost art of verbal storytelling. <br /> <br />When thinking about what made this book \\"important\\", a few thoughts came to me.  First, the book has to has achieved some sort of notoriety/popularity and this book passes that criteria.     Some non-regular readers have heard of or read this which is a good litmus test for noteriety.  Second, this book is extremely readable.  It is brief but engaging and written in the simplest of prose.  People who never read can pick this up without intimidation and take something away from the experience without needing an English Ph.D.  Any book that inspires non-readers to read has a certain societal importance in my book, regardless of the quality.  Be it the elderly, successfull buisness people, recovering addicts, athletes, kids or whoever...this book can appeal to all.  Of course this can have the opposite effect and many experienced readers have called this book overly simplistic and pointless and I can see where are they are coming from which is why I din't give this 5 stars.  <br /> <br />Bottom Line:  A great book that is a safe bet in the \\"ever dangerous\\" gift category.  A must have for most home libraries.
0060920084|5.0|I'll start by saying I'm a Bill Bryson fan, having started by reading his book \\"A Walk in the Woods\\". He got me reading books again after a very long pause.  As a 50-something babyboomer having grown up in Kansas before moving cross-country to Southern California 30 years ago, I found this book to offer a deeply introspective, yet hilarious, look at my childhood travels with the family.  Also, as a devoted road-tripper, I felt as if I was travelling right along with Bill in an adventure that many of us would love to take given the time and appropriate situation in our lives.  Bill's writing in this book, as well as his other books I've read, comes from a somewhat sarcastic style.  I think this is his best, at least the equal to his \\"A Walk in the Woods\\" bestseller.  The guy's got a knack for telling a story in a way that makes you feel instantly comfortable, want to travel with him - and see the humor,delight and yet experience insight into life's travels.  If you are the kind of person who longs for the open road and appreciates a very genuine and intellectually humorous point of view, you will love this book.
0060537639|4.0|It seems that many of the readers of this book are of a similar position in that the author presents little hard evidence for \\"his\\" theory. That said, there is a lot in the book that is factual and for that the book is a good read. If you're into this sort of reading, then certainly do not stop with this book. It is not the last word on the subject. I strongly suggest reading Maps of the Ancient Sea Kings. Almost every book of this sort refer to it. And often they misrepresent it. Aside from the usual \\"there's no evidence\\" argument, my biggest problem with the book is that there is a wealth of ancient artifacts found in mesoamerica that indicate contact with Europeans, Arabs and Africans long before the dates that are ascribed to the Chinese here, yet ALL that evidence is carefully side stepped and only what refers to Chinese contact is brought into play. Although Gavin has experience in the Navy, I don't feel that that knowledge brought very much new to the table, aside from the endless references to following the current. The other big problem I have with his theory is that the Chinese supposedly mapped the entire New World and brought various advanced sciences to South Americans in only 3 years. In fact, it's stated that it took the Chinese 2.5 years to reach South America, leaving and 6 months to do everything and return home! I applaud Gavin for his effort to further our understanding and I hope that some of his theories will be researched by others more scientifically. For a much more scholarly book on the subject, I recommend Before Columbus by Cyrus H. Gordon.
