B000002LHX|3.0|Batman was Prince biggest commercial succes since his 1984 hit album Purple Rain. Album sales had flagged down eversince, despite (or perhaps on account of) his everchanging styles. Batman is an album which is greatly in service of the motion picture. Less orchestrated and with sparser instrumentation, the album sounds dark and stripped down. The rich diversity of predecessing album is gone. It is elaborate to please the casual listener and in support of the film. Despite that Prince makes room for his known themes of love, sex, religion and the struggle between good and evil. Perhaps this is why the Batman protject was so well suited for him. Batdance is a wellcrafted popsong with a rich and inteligent use of samples from the movie. Partyman is a plain fun funk song that works on any party. The Future depicts the atmosphere of the film beatifully. The pumping beats make it a great funkrock tune that works great when played loud on the speakers. Trust and Electric Chair are easy accessible popsongs that work just great. Scandalous is one of these ballads you simply love or hate. But it is way better than \\"Arms Of Orion\\" which is too pleasing and sweet for my taste. The whole album is consistent and has no fillers. Every song is wellcrafted and most rise above the average popsong. But if you measure it up against all other albums Prince made in the 80ties, you have too conclude that there is nothing \\"new\\" on this album. Prince made the perfect album for the film, sometimes pure fun, sometimes dark and dramatic sounding. But still it restrained his creativity to a point, that the album can't level up to most of his catalogue from that decade.
B00005JNZJ|3.0|-Spoiler Alert-  The premise of the movie is that Eaon is a secret 'terrorist'/freedom fighter/assasin, out to eliminate Trevor Goodchild, the corrupt leader of a future Utopia/Dystopia in a post-apocalypse world 400 years into the future. But of course there's more to the story.  She discovers a hidden truth:     The plague that destroyed most of humanity way back in 2011 had left the survivors sterile, and what people had thought were newborn babies were in fact implanted clone embryos.      Society had become a sterile museum piece, with no fertile offspring, no new ideas or growth was possible and the world had become a meaningless, perfect but unchanging island of technology.      On the other hand, death has been banished - as clones take the place of children, individuals had for centuries been succeeded by their carbon copies.  So while individuals had aged and passed, their DNA blueprints had endured.    And so the question:  Is life so precious that it should be preserved if technology makes it possible is invented?  The answer: No.     That position - that Cloning is Good - is taken by the villains. The moral: Death is necessary..  As carbon copies we lose our individuality and our sacred concept of pure free will is degraded as our abilities and attributes become tracable and assigned to our DNA instead of our personal decisions.    And thus humanity in the current definition ends, and we become simple cogs in a soul-less machine/society. Eaon sees this, as she describes the citizenry as 'walking ghosts'.     Like Venice, embalmed in the 1850's into a museum-area for tourists, so too would the Eaon Flux Future be a bleak and meaningless existence. Inflexible, narrow, devoid of uncertainty and the pleasure or pain of a dynamic possibilities.    So .. Eaon figures out who the good guys are.  She Arranges through a long and overly complex plot to kill the bad guys, thereby freeing the future from it's well-intentioned but wrong-headed techno-overlords, andlives happily ever after in a fertile world - until her certain death in the distant future, which is exactly as it should be.    In the end the city wall is broken and a reborn humanity is again free to flood outward into a rejuvinated natural world, a new Garden of Eden with a limitless future.    Hooray!..    Charlize Theron looks like a stunningly perfect ballerina sculpture from every angle, absolutely hypnotizing, like a poised Leni-Reifenstahl Uber-Athlete made of porcelain. At 29, I'm glad she made this movie. The world wants to see her beauty, and as gravity catches up with her it's likely she'll never look this good again.    But sadly..there wasn't enough personality in this film - the sterility was deeper than the surface.  Every single sentence felt like a movement of a chess piece on an inorganic 3D backboard which really needed more verve and charm. The total abstraction of 'society', while necessary to the story, felt shallow.     If we're meant to root for humanity - we needed to see it.  I didn't see anything on the screen worth saving - instead we were supposed to be rooting for a deeper, more complex humanity which the filmakers didn't decide to show us, probably due to time-constraints and lack of imagination.  They've built themselves a magnificent edifice, but there wasn't any jelly in this donut.  Just cement sculpture and beautiful acrobatics.    Good movies that make somewhat similar points about our DNA-enhanced/cloned dystopic future, but with different styles and emphasises.. are George Lucas's THX-1138 (1970), Gattaca(1997), Equilibrium(2000), Code 46(2003) and The Island (2005).     The other direction for modern Sci-Fi is Man-vs-Robot, or computer intelligence. Some movies in that genre are I-Robot (2004), A.I. Artificial Intelligience (1999), the Matrix movies, and the sublime Bladerunner(1982).     And then there's man vs. Alien, but that's a whole other story, And from there there's Man vs. the One Ring & the Orc Army, or Potter vs. Golden Snitch.  Fantasy has a place.    Sci-Fi represents a deep vein of Metaphysical BS which Hollywood should continue to mine - I wait with baited breath.

0553381687|5.0|I have not read the sequels to this book, but I can say that this book is easily the most enjoyable book I have ever read (including Tolkien). At first I thought I would never be able to remember all the characters that Martin keeps introducing but he gives them all enough attention relative to their importance that the narrative of countless linked subplots flows seamlessly. His characterisation is brilliant, especially for female characters. This is the first book that I have read that didn't seem to waste space. Every chapter is nice and short and delivers plenty of plot development. Almost every chapter seemed to contain a story twist, varying from small and delightful to shocking. After reading this book, it feels as if the bar for fantasy writing (although fantasy elements are only subtle in this book) has been raised much higher. Compared to some other things I've seen rated 5 stars, this easily deserves 6.

0895260131|4.0|Before I saw this book title (I can't remember where I first ran across it), if asked, I would have said that Islam was a peaceful religion, that, like many other religions in history, has been hijacked by evil-doers.  But when I saw this book, I wondered.  Could he be right?  I decided to read it, and give the author a chance to make his point.<br /><br />I am acquainted with some American Muslims who would argue against this, but I wonder if they aren't plagued by their own bias.  After all, who wants to think badly of their own religion and/or ethnic ancestors?  I was shocked to learn that many non-Arab Muslims have not actually read (don't understand) their own holy book, that they merely recite passages from it in the original Arabic.<br /><br />This book seems very well researched. The author appears to be conscious of the likelihood of an anti-Muslim bias, and I believe it inspired him to study his subject harder.  He gives many suggestions for further reading.  He explores the current media line on Islam, the history of Islamic/Judeo-Chrisian relations, makes conclusions, and provides his evidence at every step.  And in a feature I loved, he presents ideas for defeating the enemy.<br /><br />Another person that picked up my copy commented that it was very repetitive - the author says some of the same things over and over.  I agree this is true, however he has a purpose.  In his discussion of an individual point he presents the evidence that backs it up.  Some evidence applies to multiple points.  I did not find any repitition to pointless, only mildly tedious on occasion.  Additionally, the prose is highly readable.<br /><br />One thing I found somewhat annoying in this book is that the author uses a comparison of Islam and Christianity as part of his framework.  I myself am of Christian ancestry, but was not raised in any particular faith.  I have spiritual beliefs, but they do not match closely enough with any specific religion for me to join one.  My annoyance was b/c I felt he was assuming his readership to be Christian.  However, if his intended audience is the American public, that is not statistically unreasonable.<br /><br />Although I would rather that the author's hypothesis were not true, at this time, I believe the author has made his point.  I now intend to investigate the issue further, and am very grateful to have had this possible truth brought to my attention.  I have already acquired some additional reading, on both \\"sides\\" of this issue, in addition to a translation of the Quran.<br /><br />I would recommend this book to everyone as a starting point for exploring this potentially (if he's right) vital issue.one. However, if his intended audience is the American public, that is not statistically unreasonable.   <br /> <br />Although I would rather that the author's hypothesis were not true, at this time, I believe the author has made his point.  I now intend to investigate the issue further, and am very grateful to have had this possible truth brought to my attention.  I have already acquired some additional reading, on both \\"sides\\" of this issue, in addition to a translation of the Quran. <br /> <br />I would recommend this book to everyone as a starting point for exploring this potentially (if he's right) vital issue.

B00003CXCW|5.0|Nominated for eleven Oscars, this movie is about a fictional silent film star Norma Desmond played by Gloria Swanson whose fictional character has not worked for decades. The retired star lives in a large mansion on Sunset Boulevard in Beverly Hills with her young \\"house guest\\" i.e.: Holden's character. He is a thirty year old screen writer, about twenty years her junior. The idea here is that she has been rejected by Hollywood as being too old to work. Discarded by the industry, she lives in a fantasy world of isolation in a decaying mansion waiting for her next big picture. She has latched onto the Holden character as a companion.<br /><br />In the end it won just 3 Oscars in 1951 for art, writing, and music. Billy Wilder won a writing Oscar after six prior nominations and one prior Oscar. Overall, it was beaten by the 5 Oscar winning Bette Davis movie All About Eve.<br /><br />This defeat at the Oscars in itself has much irony. The triumph of the Davis movie at the Oscars kills the theory that older actresses cannot work in Hollywood. The Bette Davis movie beat out Sunset Boulevard and the fictional Norma Desmond, the latter a movie that implies that older female actresses are not wanted in Hollywood. But the winner Davis was nominated for 11 Oscars, won two, and she made 103 movies working until she was 81. So to me that creates some doubt about the idea that this film makes a real statement about old actresses in Holywood. Gloria Swanson had only made one movie since 1934, similar to the Norma character, but her career did make a modest comeback in later years and she was in 5 more movies after the present success.<br /><br />The Academy members thought that this movie had some merit for innovation, art, etc. Perhaps at the time it was not the the best in its day, and it was certainly an uphill battle against a good Bette Davis movie in the 1940s. But over time it has survived as well if not better than the Bette Davis movie, and emerged as a film noir classic.<br /><br />There are a number of good performances and nice touches in the movie including a 5 minute appearance by Cecil B. DeMille playing himself, a Young Jack Web as Artie Green - a friend of Holden's character, and Nancy Olson playing Betty Schaefer who is a screen writer working with the Holden character. Also, Erich von Stroheim playing Max von Mayerling, the butler, is solid.<br /><br />Bottom line: A film noir classic set in a decaying mansion inhabited by an aging silent film star who has lost her mind. You will either love this movie or hate it. I prefer something more upbeat but thought that it was entertaining, less excitement than Double Indeminity and overall not as attractive as Casablanca.<br /><br />The movie is a survivor and now a classic from the film noir period. It is among the best of the period with Casablanca, Double Indeminity and the Bogart-Bacall's and Edward G. 0060899190|5.0|This book is not only a spectacular collection of artwork, but also an insight into the psyche of our collective humanity.  Here is the essence of our insecurities and private desires, laid open in a thought-provoking and often humorous way.  Some of the postcards will make you laugh, others will make you cry, and many will make you question the secrets you have in your own life.  A sometimes gut-wrenching book, I think it should be on the coffee table of every household. A definite must-buy.
B000002UAO|5.0|Today is December 3, 2005. Forty years ago Rubber Soul saw the light. Forty years... the same time that Moses and his people were in the desert... Will Rubber Soul finally get into the promise land reserved for the greatest albums of all time? Surely many people, like I do, already put it there, but truth is that common opinion overlooks this album, paying much more attention to other Beatles masterpieces like Revolver, Sgt. Pepper's, the White Album or Abbey Road. Because the Beatles alone are a whole world, and in the Beatles world Rubber Soul is like Odessey And Oracle (the Zombies) or Forever Changes (Love) in the music world: overlooked. I know that many Beatles fans consider Rubber Soul to be a masterpiece as well (some of them say that \\"every Beatles album is a masterpiece\\"), and some serious fans usually say things like \\"Rubber Soul is the beginning of the greatness of the Beatles\\" or \\"Rubber Soul is a period of transition\\". I agree that Rubber Soul started something, but my view is that Rubber Soul is not just a \\"first step\\" but it is a peak in the Beatles career; and the true transitional album was Help!, not Rubber Soul. <br /> <br />Rubber Soul is my favourite Beatles album, and I have some (always subjective) reasons to love this album more than others. 1) The songwriting: John, my favourite Beatle, here is at his best, lyrically and melodically; Paul will get better in Revolver, but here he also wrote a couple of his eternal classics; and both of George songs are outstanding among the whole George's career. 2) The instrumentation: some successful experiments like the sitar (\\"Norwegian Wood\\"), the fuzz bass (\\"Think For Yourself\\") and a speed-up piano (\\"In My Life\\"); new sounds in the guitars, more melodic bass and arguably the very best Ringo's drumming with the Beatles. 3) The production: it is true that this album is more carefully produced than previous Beatles albums, but it's not overproduced like the next albums (especially Sgt. Pepper's); I findthe production of Rubber Soul to be in its right place, without all that lovely but sometimes excessive orchestration, a true rock (or folk rock) record. These are just a few points about why I prefer Rubber Soul over other famous Beatles albums; still Revolver is among my very favourite albums of all time and probably the most important step in rock music, Sgt. Pepper's is always a magic journey, the White Album rocks my day beyond its mess, and Abbey Road is the previous step to Heaven. <br /> <br />John wrote three masterpieces from Rubber Soul that always are included in my personal \\"Top 10 best Beatles songs ever\\" list. \\"Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)\\", beyond the famous Indian sitar and the wood from Norway, has a mystery peaceful spirit from nowhere; the lyrics are so good that they were included in a classic English poetry anthology. Also from nowhere land is \\"Nowhere Man\\" with its beautiful and fresh harmonies; although this track is known as the first Beatles song that doesn't talk about romantic love, the song is showing us a lonely man who love is all he needs and is waiting for it. And \\"In My Life\\" is a favourite of everyone, with its nostalgic words which talk about the past but seem to talk about the future too; the baroque piano solo is delicious. <br /> <br />The album has two classic ballads that became very covered just a few days after the album was released. \\"Michelle\\" is from Paul's garden: delicate acoustic guitars, sweet bass, a guitar solo that seems to play a different melody and some French lyrics make this a timeless classic. The even more acoustic \\"Girl\\" is another proof of why John was at the peak of his songwriting during those last months of 1965, singing about this dreamed girl loved despite her behaviour; a little gem for Rubber Soul. <br /> <br />\\"Drive My Car\\" is an amazing opener and maybe the only pure rocker of the album; the guitar-bass combination in this song is just perfect, and the story is very funny. Some people say that this track has nothing to do with the folk spirit of Rubber Soul and shouldn't be there (they usually prefer the mutilated American version of the album, which starts with \\"I've Just Seen A Face\\"), but I don't agree at all with them, because beyond the fact that Rubber Soul could fairly be called a folk rock record, the true magic of this album resides in its diversity of sounds. <br /> <br />It seems that those were not happy days in Paul's romantic life, since he wrote two almost anti-love songs which seem to have been dedicated to his girlfriend Jane Asher: \\"You Won't See Me\\" and \\"I'm Looking Through You\\". The former has a Help!-sound, with almost no guitars and based on some interesting bass lines, piano and impressive drumming, plus joyful backing vocals. The other one is an enjoyable track as well, driven by acoustic guitars until those exciting electric guitar lines appear. <br /> <br />Now it's time for the George's paragraph. George has two songs here, and they are indeed very good. Just for the fuzz bass, \\"Think For Yourself\\" is a song that deserves attention, but it also says some interesting things to think about (for ourselves). And \\"If I Needing Someone\\" is George at his best Jim/Roger McGuinn version, with that Byrdish guitar and those Byrdish harmonies. <br /> <br />\\"The Word\\" deserves another paragraph. A prophetic song about (or perhaps part of the reason of) the feeling of Universal Love of the second part of the 1960's years. Don't miss the message of this fantastic pseudo-psychedelic song. <br /> <br />Three more tracks that could be called as \\"fillers\\" (in comparison to the best songs) complete this album; however, each of them have something good to say. \\"What Goes On\\" is a country rocker which seems to be no more than an excuse for Ringo to sing a track, but it has a good rhythm and includes (for those days) a quite long guitar solo. \\"Wait\\" is filled with a very interesting tone pedal guitar. \\"Run For Your Life\\" is not genius songwriting, but John's vocals are really great there; the line \\"that's the end, little girl\\" makes the song be an adequate closer. <br /> <br />What more can I say? Every time I listen to this album is a special time, so I try not to listen to it too often to keep it special. But today is its birthday, so today will be another special day. <br /> <br />If I didn't bore you, I invite you to visit my website dedicated to this album: <br /> <br />[...] <br />

0765348780|2.0|A close cousin, as many have pointed out, is Glen Cook's Black Company series. However, they are also very different and not in a way that flatters Erikson. Cook's protagonists are gritty, vulnerable, often outgunned and seem to portray soldiers quite well. The plots are usually tight, simple and logical.<br /><br />The Mazalan books, in constrast, are huge and full of superpowered characters and magic. In many ways, they read almost as comic books. Which is fun, for a while, then it wears off. The fact that almost every member of the 8th Sapper Squad (or whatever Whiskey Jack's unit is called) turns out to be so powerful is odd for a seemingly minor unit which isn't quite depicted as being the Rangers or SAS of the Malazan Army.<br /><br />The plots are complex, but did not really engage me and they don't seem to lead anywhere. In fact, what ended the series for me was a passage, in book 4 (House of Chains) where one character just _lectures_ another about the cleverness of the Empress's latest ploy. To me, it seemed contrived, rather than brilliant or significant. I felt that I was being lectured about how brilliant Erikson's plot twists are. I stopped and could never quite pick it up again.<br /><br />Why did I stick with it for so long? There are lots of inventive ideas and the world's background can be first rate, at times.<br /><br />On a side note, I found Erikson's approach to women characters, in a very, very violent world, interesting. Basically, his world seems to postulate physical/muscular equality, though he never mentions it. As a result, many of the women are just as liable to be soldiers as the men and there is no hint of a \\"weaker sex\\". Kind of an artifact, but it works.<br /><br />I think Erikson should finish up the series as planned, take a break and then write something else. In doing so, he should tighten his plots, throw out his 15th level characters (sorry, bit of D&D jargon slipping out...) and trim his books considerably. In other words, his editor should own him, big time. But he should keep the intricate worldbuilding that has made the Malazan series so enjoyable. If so, we would be getting a pretty impressive new voice in the Fantasy landscape.r words, his editor should own him, big time. But he should keep the intricate worldbuilding that has made the Malazan series so enjoyable. If so, we would be getting a pretty impressive new voice in the Fantasy landscape.
B00005JOHI|4.0|If you've never seen or read Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, this latest Pride and Prejudice re-make starring Keira Knightley  is an okay introduction.  <br /> <br />If you're a huge Jane Austen fan, then this movie is still okay for you. It's not nearly as disappointing as might have feared. <br />  <br />I had concerns going into this movie, but none of them were borne out. The pace was rushed, but not too rushed; it jam-pack the story into 2 short hours, and unfortunately, certain storylines & characters were condensed to make them fit (Wickham-gasp!-was but a sidenote! ). Keira knightly brilliantly played Jennifer Ehle as Elizabeth Bennett. The plot and spirit stayed more-or less true to the book. I guess cliff notes are sufficient sometimes. <br /> <br />Also, this remake adds something new to the Jane Austen cannon: verisimilitude to true 1700'ss life. Unlike other period remakes, which always show immaculate parlors, tidy living, and impeccably coiffed Young Ladies, this world was dirty and messy. Dogs roamed free through the Bennett home, food was grabbed and gobbled at the table, gentlemen weren't clean-shaven, and ladies obviously did not have the advantage of shampoo, hairspray, or styling products. The set felt more like noisy, dirty Colonial Williamsburg come to life, and not the hushed, immaculate parlors of BBC fantasy. <br /> <br />But the best thing about this remake was the dance scenes. \\"I do lore a ball\\" is something Austen characters are wont to matter, and that passion comes off well on-screen here. Steady-cam images put you in the action, and the constant movement makes it fun to follow the intrigue. There is, however, too much of a good thing, and by the end of the second ball scene, I really wanted the cinematographer to go find a tripod! <br /> <br />Overall, I enjoyed this movie. While it's not the triumph of the BBC remake, it's also not the disaster I feared it would be. The sweetness that appealed to me when I first read it, of characters who long for love but don't hook up til they get married, as well as the sarcasm & humor that only struck me later, all comes across on this movie screen. And probably will on DVD, too (no rush to the theater for this one).  <br /> <br />  <br />
B000BGR0OM|5.0|The greatest hits set, \\"The Ultimate Collection\\" offers ample evidence of this band's ability to create great songs. They were quite a formidable singles machine. <br />The first dozen or so cuts remind you how they were all over the radio/MTV for a few years, and you'll find you know these songs by heart. <br />After opening with a new cut, and the thin \\"Love is a Stranger\\", you get one classic after another.  <br />\\"Sweet Dreams\\", with that fat synth and those soulful, evocative yet still icy-cool vocals of Annie Lennox, became their introduction to the pop world. They had a signature sound, and then spent the next two albums refining and expanding it. <br />\\"Who's That Girl\\" and \\"Here Comes The Rain Again\\" are two exquisite singles that follow in \\"Dreams\\" vein, but I'm delighted to see (and hear) the joyous \\"Right By Your Side\\" making the list here.  <br />The next three powerhouse tunes come off their \\"third\\" album, with \\"Would I Lie To You\\" showing off Dave Stewart's exuberant, chord-spewing guitar work.  \\"Angel\\" is a soft, haunting, sweet pop-soul confection, and \\"Sisters\\" is an anthemic, R&B stomp with twitchy guitars from Mr. Stewart and towering vocals from none other than Miss Aretha Franklin. <br />After than opening salvo, the quality declines...but not by much (except that \\"I Need A Man\\" fiasco...)...I thought \\"17 Again\\" was particularly affecting (as opposed to 'affected'...see above)... <br /> <br />Overall, with nice remastering and 19 songs, this is an easy five-star package. You couldn't have asked for more in a single-disc summation of this killer band's catalogue.
B000B8QEZG|4.0|I gotta hand it to Madonna. Just when I thought American Life was going to be the ruination of her career, she went back to the basics and came out with an album based entirely, and I mean ENTIRELY, on what shot her to stardom in the first place: dance music. In terms of innovation, this is not Madonna's finest hour. As good as it is, nothing can top Ray of Light. Overall, this is a very decent collection of dance songs. Let's take a look at it track-by-track: <br /> <br />1) HUNG UP: Everyone knows this song. This is a very catchy nu disco-house track, suited perfectly for clubs and dancefloors. But it's not perfect. It's downfall? The lyrics are a bit underhand for an advanced artist like Madonna. Unfortunately, this lyrical disadvantage seems to plague a few more tracks on the album. <br /> <br />2) GET TOGETHER: My favorite track. This one fronts a perfect breakbeat, backed by an awesome, dreamy tranceline. The production, though top-notch like the rest of the tracks here, really takes the cake. It has a DJ Tiesto-like quality, mind you, I'm comparing this production to that of the #1 DJ in the world. But once again, the lyrics, especially in the chorus fall short of Madonna's introspective, creative ability. All the same, this small faux pas is completely overshadowed by the brilliance of the production. <br /> <br />3) SORRY: I have mixed feelings about this track. The lyrics are a little bit, but not totally, better than the first two tracks. Madonna saying \\"I'm sorry\\" in about six different languages at different points in the track adds some innovation but does not nearly compensate for the so-so dance beat and cliched \\"don't say you're sorry\\" theme of the song. <br /> <br />4) FUTURE LOVERS: This is a great track. The first minute and a half entails Madonna muttering introspective lines about love over an electro-ambient tone, then it breaks into a bass-booming display of absolutely brilliant production and lyrics. It's only one of two tracks here where Mirwais Ahmadzai collaborates on the production, which is unfortunate because he's brilliant and he proves it on this track as much as he did on the two previous Madonna albums. <br /> <br />5) I LOVE NEW YORK: Four words- what was she thinking? This has got to be the worst track on the album. The lyrics are absolutely horrendous and the beat is not even that great. Take these lyrics for example: \\"I don't like cities, but I love New York. Other places make me feel like a dork.\\" The chorus ain't much better either: \\"Other cities always make me mad. Other places always make me sad. No other city ever made me glad except New York. I love New York.\\" Can she not do any better than that? <br /> <br />6) LET IT WILL BE: Much more introspective track than the previous. The production entails Mirwais Ahmadzai once again (thank God). It sort of sounds like a throwback to Ray of Light, not that that's a bad thing, but I would hate to see her just flatline in that era. There's not much more I can say, but it's good. <br /> <br />7) FORBIDDEN LOVE: Probably the softest track on the album (not like that's saying much), it's more mid-tempo. The lyrics are great, the beat is house-ish, and the synths are awesome. The one thing it could have done without was the overused vocoder. Other than that, it's a very easy listen. <br /> <br />8) JUMP: I wasn't all too impressed with this one. The chorus is too predictable (\\"Are you ready to jump? Get ready to jump. Don't ever look back oh baby.\\") It sounds like something too similar to her Like a Prayer era. It fits in okay with the rest of the tracks here, but there are better ones. <br /> <br />9) HOW HIGH: This track suffers the same lyrical chorus problem as the one before it. The beat is decent, but the chorus is subpar. There's nothing very introspective here, the theme of this track is about fame and fortune, something very cliched with high-profile music stars. The best quality of this track is that it is catchy, but that's all I can give it. <br /> <br />10) ISAAC: My second favorite track on the album. I believe the man singing on here is singing a Hebrew prayer (probably an ode to Madonna's Kabballah fad). The violins, guitar and beat combine to form a very well produced track, though not as dancy as the others. The lyrics are probably the most innovative on the album. This track also has a bit of the Ray of Light throwback feel to it as well.  <br /> <br />11) PUSH: Very heavy basslines and a jungly, almost hip-hop-ish beat characterize this song, which is interesting because it steers away from the techno-base the album is built upon. This isn't so much a bad thing because it does offer diversity. The downfall here is that the lyrics are, once again, very crappy and sung way too fast outside of the chorus. It sounds a lot like when she tried to rap on American Life... And we all know how that went over, like a fart in church. <br /> <br />12) LIKE IT OR NOT: Decent closer to the album. The beat and synth has a very electro-feel to it, but it's the lyrics make it here. They're not all that innovative, but they are powerful, which is a good thing. The chorus is: \\"This is who I am. You can like it or not. You can love me or leave me, cause I'm never gonna stop.\\" These words reassure us that Madonna is here to stay and that's the theme of the song. <br /> <br />As you can see, the lyrics in a few of the songs could have used some work, but the top-notch production here makes this album regardless of if it's Madonna or anyone else. I would definitely recommend this album to any Madonna or electronic music fan.
B0000029DD|5.0|Why do the good die young? <br /> <br />Listen to Grace and try to fathom what Jeff Buckley would have become had he not died at 1997 at age 30. Sketches for My Sweetheart the Drunk and live albums like Mystery White Boy and Live at Sin-E only serve to further outline Buckley's blooming greatness. <br /> <br />But Grace...Grace. The album is a beautiful debut, filled with precise, poetic lyric imagery and Buckley's soaring, 3-and-a-half octaves voice. The cover of Leonard Cohen's \\"Halleljuha\\" is possibly the best version of the song, serene and fragile; \\"Lover You Should've Come Over\\" is achingly intense. Buckley dips between grungey rock on \\"Eternal Life\\" and the art-tripfest of \\"Dream Brother\\"; \\"Last Goodbye\\" is a sweet love song and \\"Mojo Pin\\", the album's opener, is like Robert Plant as choirboy. <br /> <br />All things considered, if you've heretofore missed out on Jeff Buckley, this album is certainly your saving Grace.

073945529X|5.0|Blink! explores the phenomena we have all experianced, that initial feeling we get when exposed to something new.   <br /> <br />Initially I was a bit skeptical of the premise.  It sounded like one of the New Age self-awareness books.  I was mistaken.  Instead, Gladwell makes two, very important, statements.   <br /> <br />First, those gut feelings can be very accurate when an expert gets them.  That is, someone who has a lot of experiance with an item or situation is able to judge that situtation rapidly and fairly accurately.  Further, expertise does not mean college diplomas but experiance.  We are all experts, to a large degree, at reading faces because we have been doing that all of our lives.  So we can rapidly, subconciously, arrive at a conclusion about someone we meet for the first time because of their expressions.  Our brains perform activities below the conscious level, and our conscious selves can access the results.  (In a way, this is a neat argument for consciousness being an artifact of cerebration and not the other way around.) <br /> <br />Second, even experts can be fooled when the cues we subconsiously use to size up an item or situation lead us down a the wrong path.   <br /> <br />Blink! is about intuition, and illustrates the power, and flaws, with intuitive thinking.  It is another demonstration of the superior power of rational thought over intuition.

0679422714|4.0|There has been a lot of controversy over this book, though some of it is questionable. A fair amount of the criticism seems to come from far-left sympathisers or nationalist Chinese that cannot accept that Mao was bad. In order to understand them, you must look at how they talk about Iris Chang. There are significant academic flaws in her research, yet they robustly defend her against \\"Japanophiles\\" and \\"Imperialist Japanese\\". I wonder how they would have reacted if Jung Chang had been writing about General Tojo. <br /> <br />Still more comes from academics that are worried the book is too \\"biased\\". As a historian myself, I wonder how they can be quite so excited about that, given that ALL historical works are biased. For one thing, the writer has enough interest in the subject area to research it at all, and normally approaches the topic with pre-formed ideas and assumptions, even if they would not realise it. The general public may look upon \\"history\\" believing that it is about distinguishing \\"right & wrong\\", trying to be \\"neutral\\", etc. That is not the case - only armchair historians believe it. In the study of history, one must take any work with a pinch of salt. <br /> <br />\\"Mao\\" is in my mind mostly good, with some flaws from various scholarly mistakes. The \\"wave tactics\\" in the Korean War have been shown to be an exaggeration (the Chinese had numerical superiority but not in the vast numbers previously believed). But this book is still better than any other in demonstrating what Mao was really like. Philip Short said that Mao \\"was a great poet, a visionary and, I would argue, a military strategist of genius.\\" Well, I would argue that stating such things merely clouds the issue of Mao's role in setting China's development back 10-20 years, through the failed Great Leap Forward and chaotic Cultural Revolution. Mainland Chinese cannot read books that purport to be neutral, as their government controls academic discussion of Mao. So what they need, more than anything else, is a book to clearly set out his flaws and expose them to the harsh reality of daylight. <br /> <br />Mao: the unknown story has its flaws, as many have pointed out. But in the words of the Chinese Communist Party it is \\"70% good and 30% bad\\".

074322454X|5.0|-I read this book after first watching the mini series, and I agree with an earlier reviewer that the movie was better than the book, but the book is still a worth while read. The book is written in a very conversational style, with lots of quotes and stories from the men that fought the war, and runs about 340 pages, all of which are fast paced and moving. <br /> <br />Taking the company thru intense drilling and training in Alabama, through the deployment, its various battles and finally the conquest and occupation of Germany, the book brings to life what life was like for the men of Easy Company there and their relationships between them. Particularily interesting where the letters and the diary of one of the men, Jackson, a Harvard educated soldier whose accounts and writing really helped make the book as personal as it was.  <br /> <br />The book doesn't devote a lot of time to the explicit accounts of battle, which I felt would have improved it quite a bit. It closes with a \\"where are they now\\" segment which I found interesting to see how the men spent the remainder of their lives. This aside, when reading, it is hard to not feel like you are with the men through the whole conflict which makes the book ahrd to put down.  <br /> <br />Overall, this is a very enjoyable read, and will give the reader a great insight to the men who fought the war and what their lives were like.
B000B8QEYC|4.0|If you are looking for a MEGA HIT along the lines of ORINOCO FLOW or ONLY TIME on Enya's new album- AMARANTINE, you won't find it.<br /><br />However, if your personalized homemade Enya greatest hits mixed CD includes songs such as ONLY IF, ANYWHERE IS, WILD CHILD, CARIBBEAN BLUE, & BOOK OF DAYS, what you will find on AMARANTINE are 3 songs similar to the ones mentioned above that will fit in nicely with those songs for your listening pleasure.<br /><br />ITS IN THE RAIN, LONG LONG JOURNEY, & AMARANTINE are 3 songs that I expect to get \\"single\\" consideration.<br /><br />All 3 songs follow the long time Enya formula of Layered vocals harmonizing over a catchy hook.<br /><br />The rest of the album is interesting & includes 3 songs (LESS THAN A PEARL, THE RIVER SINGS, & WATER SHOWS THE HIDDEN HEART) sung in a make believe language called LORIAN.<br /><br />Enya also succeeds in painting a very good visual picture in her songs. As you close your eyes & listen to AMID THE FALLING SNOW you hear the music & can visualize the snow falling around you.<br /><br />Overall AMARANTINE has been worth the wait for Enya fans & I would recommend buying it today.
B00006ADD5|3.0|The single best thing about this movie is its desert photography.  The story itself lacks intensity, which is surprising since it is about war.<br /><br />Lawrence is portrayed as someone who makes you say \\"what's wrong with that man?\\".  In some scenes, Peter O'Toole has an insane look on his face and behaves irrationally.  In some scenes he seems to think he is a god.  Then in some scenes he gives up, demoralized.  All in all, he is utterly confused and at times delusional.<br /><br />Why does a war movie appear so bland?  The victories that are won are apparently not important.  If they are of any importance, the film fails to show that to us.  There is absolutely no drama to any of the battle scenes.  There is no fear leading up to them, no intensity at all.  I fault the much heralded director for that, as well as the much heralded actors.  This isn't a bad movie but it is extremely overrated.<br /><br />Why do the Arabs keep calling him Aurence? Why did Lawrence go nuts and hit the guy?<br /><br />This is one of those many many movies that are given credit as being among the greatest of all time, but clearly are not. It held my interest for nearly four hours, though it took about three sessions to get through it.<br /><br />It has the makings of a good film, but it is in dire need of a tremendous amount of editing and re-shooting. B000AY3KN0|4.0|First I let me state for the record KING KONG is a Great Movie in any of the current versions. Cooper, Schoedsack, Rose and O'Brien proved themselves geniuses in creating KONG. My review is based on owning and viewing 3 of 4 Laser Disc and 3 VHS Releases. The 2 Disk Collectors Edition (T7431)is beautifully packaged in an embossed oversized tin. Within are 5 what appear to be Lobby Cards, and a  pressbook reprint. (The book contains story boards as well as cast and crew notes. Also included is a 1 sheet Movie poster offer($3.25) The discs are securely contained in very nicely illustrated foldout cardboard case     Now to the Discs themselves the film appears to me to be  identical to the earlier 60 Anniversary Laser Disc although run time is listed as 4 minutes longer. I must say I found the commentary track by Ray Harryhausen and Ken Ralston annoying, sounding as informative as an episode Mystery Science Theater. (Sorry Ray)The commentary done for Criterion Laser Disc by Ronald Haver superior in every way. The Audio is MONO and not the Stereo of the earlier 60th Anniversary Laser Disc. The follow on documentaries are well worth watching. The \\"I'm King Kong\\" profile of Cooper is great while The Making of... seemed a bit disapointing too many talking heads to many flashing cuts. It is still very good and loaded with information. I do have mixed feelings on the RECREATION of the \\"Lost Spider Pit Sequence\\"    The Creation Clip and commentary by Ray Harryhausen is excellent. MISSING IS \\"Turners\\" COLORISED Version of King Kong.      P.S.  If someone would like to see what the Willis O'Brien's \\"Lost Spider Pit Sequence\\" would of looked like. I recommend you view  O'Brien's 1957 \\"Black Scorpion\\".         So in short it is very hit and miss. This release is \\"good\\" but \\"not definitive\\"! This release is more about Cooper and less about the Wizard Special Effects and Willis O'Brien. True Cooper's life story is incredible and itself would be a great film.     As to the \\"Three\\" Different Warner 2 Disc packages released it a matter of preference The versions differ only in packaging a some      novelty items the Discs appear to have the same content.  King Kong (Collector's Edition)  $39.98 $25.99   King Kong (2-Disc Special Edition)  $26.98 $17.99  The third includes the same King Kong content plus the sequels  The King Kong Collection (King Kong 2-Disc Special Edition/Son of Kong/Mighty Joe Young) (1933)           $39.98 $25.99    Please notice many of the reviews were done before 22 NOV. 2005 release date.  Enjoy
0060764899|5.0|Every day, somewhere in the world, someone reads or revisits the overarching truth of Lewis's book - namely that Aslan was, is, and always shall be victorious. Though the wrapping paper of the gift that Lewis gave us in \\"The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe\\" is itself quite nice (an approach fully and wonderfully informed by early to mid twentieth century British life), it is the gift inside of the wrapping that is the true source of the book's power. Neither unnecessarily subtle nor offensively overbearing, the Christian allegory that Lewis unfolds is strong enough to be apparent to one accustomed to Christian narrative and imagery while not so blunt as to take away from the reading experience of one without such a frame of reference. And, bonus of bonuses, it is all rolled out in an exciting adventure that is able to engage and entertain all manner of reader. 5 stars and more if more could be given.

1573301183|5.0|I've been a longtime AIC fan but never really felt the need to buy this Unplugged DVD. Only after hearing Pearl Jam's acoustic CD did I begin to want this DVD. I eventually did buy it and was moved beyond words by the performance. Layne and Jerry's voices playing off of each other created a mood no other Unplugged performance will ever rival, and the guitars, bass, and drums are all hauntingly beautiful. What makes this different from the much more publicized performance of Nirvana's is that this entire set is beautiful and mellow whereas Nirvana's changed between somewhat upbeat and then depressing. Through the entire run time each time you look at Layne you feel pain and emotion flowing through his voice, particularly in Rooster. There are no low points with this set, every song is played perfectly and fits with the other songs like it should, nothing feels out of place. Jerry's voice at no time overpowers Layne's, and it sounds great throughout. No bad things can possibly be said about this DVD, performance, or this band. This is essential listening, you can tell from the 5-star average rating after over 60 reviews that everyone loves this performance. It doesn't matter if you're a fan of AIC or a fan of grunge, if you have any feelings at all, you're bound to experience them while viewing this.

B00004HYLF|5.0|While riding in a van one day in the later '70s, a bandmate stuck in an 8-track tape and said,\\"Hey nate, listen to this guitar player\\". After about 10 minutes, I was finally able to close my frozen jaw and wipe the drool from my shirt, and asked him if I could borrow it. He didn't get it back until I bought the album. <br />  It wasn't just the guitarist - the bassist blew me away! And all those synthesizer sounds that complimented everything perfectly. I didn't even LIKE synthesizers! It wasn't just the musicianship and cool sounds either. Even today when I plug in the remastered CD, I still feel like I'm sitting in front of an old console stereo. You know, the wooden box that had funky colored fabric speaker grille cloth on each side of the front, and had a flip top center that exposed the record player, 8 track player and radio tuner. Those things sounded SSSOOOO warm.  <br />   That clear, warm production drew me in as much as anything, and that feeling didn't get lost on the remastered CD. I've been a musician for 30 years and have listened to much music, but nothing has grabbed me like that day in the van. Romantic Warrior was the reason I bought so many Stanley Clarke albums and took me on a musical journey that I'm much the richer for. <br />   In a time when disco ruled, what a dramatic departure to discover a collection of Baroque tunes played at breakneck speed on rock n' roll instruments full of funk and experimentation. A huge chunk of great music from the last 30 years exists because of this album. And most people don't even know that RTF ever existed.    <br />   This ain't just a cool album, it changed my musical life!

0380789019|3.0|There's a parallel fantasy world underneath our feet and above our roofs. It's a dark and dangerous place, akin to the \\"realm of faery\\" of ancient European folk tales.<br /><br />Most sane, respectable people aren't aware of the place. _Neverwhere_ follows the adventures of a white-collar office drone who, after an act of uncharacteristic bravery, finds himself drawn into the parallel world beneath London.<br /><br />It's a wonderful set-up, with vivid characters and settings, but ultimately I felt only moderately entertained by this one.<br /><br />Anyone who has read Douglas Adams and Terry Pratchett will find _Neverwhere's_ style and feel very familiar. I'm frankly kind of burned out on snarky, arch fantasy. If this sort of work hasn't worn out its welcome, you may enjoy it more than I did.
0060764899|5.0|I must admit that the title \\"The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe\\" is not what compelled me to read this book.  It seemed a bit too childish for me.  I am familiar with some of Lewis's other work, but this is my first trip to Narnia.  In preparation for the upcoming movie, I decided to make my first visit to Narnia.    Four Children staying in a mostly empty house can give rise to numerous potential adventures.  When a passage in a wardrobe closet leads to another world, a strange adventure is available to the children.  Narnia, where it is always been winter since the white witch became queen, has been awaiting the fulfillment of a prophecy.  When the four children arrive in fulfillment of the prophecy, they meet the mighty lion Aslan.  The great strength of this lion can only originate from one source than allows the witch to ultimately be conquered and the four children to reign as kings and queens of Narnia.    While this book is short and simplistic, the adventure has more than enough depth to capture the adult reader's attention.  While books with fauns and talking animals are normally not on my reading list, I have a great appreciation for this book.  There is certainly a reason this book has been treasured for more than fifty years and across generations of families.
B000002UA2|5.0|This is the soundtrack to the Barbet Schoeder movie \\"La Valle\\". It is their third soundtrack after the average Zabriskie Point and More. It was released during the golden Pink Floyd era, between Meddle and The Dark Side of the Moon. <br />Obviously, when a band records as many hits as Pink Floyd have, some albums get less attention. However, too often people overlook this one. Animals is a fantastic album that is highly overrated, mainly because of the fact that the songs were too long to get any airtime on the radio. Meddle is also underrated to some extent, but Obscured by Clouds, in my opinion, is the most underrated of all. <br />It is probably not the best choice for a Floyd newcommer, but for the one who has listened to the hits of 71-79, and who have overlooked this one, Obscured by Clouds is well worth purchasing. <br />When drummer Nick Mason was asked what he thought went wrong in this album, he said he thought it was a sensational LP, and right he was. This one ranks up with the best Floyd work and hopefully it will some day get the recognition it deserves. <br /> <br />So for the Floyd fans who have not heard this one yet, seriously consider purchasing it. You will not regret it. <br /> <br />For the Floyd newcomers, you should start by getting used to the Floyd with The Dark Side of the Moon, Wish You Were Here, Animals and Meddle before trying any other Pink Floyd albums. The Wall is also good, with, amongst other songs, Comfortably Numb, which is often rated as one of the best rock songs ever. Echoes is also a good compilation because it covers songs from all the periods of the band. <br /> <br />But please do not overlook this one. It will be a big mistake.

B00066N8JS|5.0|This is one reissue album you don't want to miss!  Trent Reznor is perhaps the only modern rock artist who understands what a remastered, reissued album truly should be.  And he went overkill with this one.  I will dispense with the track listing and musical critique and cut to what this reissue is all about: sound.  This version of the 1994 industrial music milestone has a standard cd audio layer, and also a multichannel / stereo SACD layer.  For those who may or may not own the original release, the remastering of the cd audio alone is worth the purchase.  For those with the proper equipment, SACD is what this album is all about.  The 5.1 mix is a revelation, taking full advantage of sacd's attributes.  An all out 360 degree sonic assault in the highest fidelity audio format avaliable to consumers today.  Even if you don't have a 5.1 surround speaker setup but happen to have a sacd decoding dvd player, the stereo sacd track is even a noticeable improvement from the cd layer, in terms of fidelity.  On the obsessive side, this album was also released as a dualdisc, featuring the same remastered cd audio on one side and the entire album in stereo AND 5.1 in advanced resolution (48khz/24-bit, if i'm not mistaken)  dvd-audio sound on the flipside.  If  you have any penchant for maximum fidelity surround sound of, finally, a great modern rock record (as opposed to jazz, classical, typical genres that call SACD home), this is one album you won't want to miss!

1400082773|5.0|I read this for one of my reading groups. Being the non-political person that I am, I was completely unaware of who this person is, but my very political girlfriend filled me in. Obama is currently a US Senator from Illinois and a hot guy in the Democratic party these days. After reading his memoir, I am a supporter. He has a fine sense of integrity and understanding about people though I fear that the political process in this country would kill that off in even the strongest individual. <br />  <br />In the early 90s, Obama was studying law at Harvard and became the first black man to be elected as President of the Harvard Law Review. The publicity engendered by this event brought him a publishing offer, so he wrote this story of his life up to that point. After winning the seat in the US Senate, the book was republished.  <br /> <br />Obama's mother was a white woman from Kansas, whose family moved to Hawaii when she was a teenager. There at the University of Hawaii, she met an African student from Kenya. They married and had Barack in the early 60s. But the father left when Barack was only 2 years old, to get his PhD at Harvard because his scholarship money was not enough to support a wife and child. Before he could complete his degree, he was summoned back to Kenya by his government and the marriage dissolved due to time and distance.  <br /> <br />So Barack was raised by his white mother and grandparents while his father took on the quality of a myth. When Barack was ten years old, his father came for a two week visit which only served to confuse Barack further. But he managed to complete highschool and college, by which time he had decided to live as a black man. <br /> <br /> After college, he went to Chicago to work as a community organizer in the ghettos of South Chicago and came face to face with the results of racism in a northern industrial city. Just before entering Harvard Law School, he finally traveled to Kenya and met his father's side of the family, finding at last the other half of his heritage.  <br /> <br />It was a fascinating book, written in a novelist's style and hard to put down. It added much to my growing fund of knowledge about Blacks in this country, their African forebears, racism and the long slow climb of the Black race in America from slaves to full citizens of this country; a climb which is far from over.  <br /> <br />I doubt that this country is ready to elect a Black President, but I am sure it will happen in my lifetime. If Obama can stay in politics and maintain the integrity he displays in his book, I would be glad to have him as President of the United States.

0156012197|5.0|At first sight, The Little Prince might just be another children's book. While it is categorized as children's literature, it is something for all. The Little Prince, combining simplicity with a beauty of expression, celebrates the imagination of children, cherishment of peace, the beauty of the mind, the preciousness of childhood, and the human spirit as a whole. The book is, as you probably expect, evolved around a little prince, a young boy who rules over his tiny planet with two extinct volcanoes, and a little flower with whom he falls in love. The little prince eventually leaves his planet and goes off to others one by one. The satirical part of the book comes in when the little prince visits several different planets, each ruled by an adult. He encounters a king, who commands his subjects and yet have none to command; a business man who only cares about the numbers of stars he owns and yet owns none; a drunkard; a lamplighter who lights his lamp every half minute or so; and a geographer. The author in some ways, mocks the narrow minded, materialistic existence of the adult world while revealing the true worth to that idealistic, imaginary world of a child.  <br />          The book is truly touching, it is exquisite. The book is combined with little bursts of laughter, little drops of sadness, and an infinite realm of imagination and the same a celebration of the truth. Pick it up, for it brings us into a level of understanding, and a new perpective towards the world that we all live in.
B00062J00S|5.0|It may seem like a bit of hyperbole to state that \\"It's a Wonderful Life\\" is the best movie ever made, but if you strip away all of the hyperbole that surrounds this movie, you will see that the assessment of it being the best movie ever made is not far from the truth.<br /><br />Frank Capra assembled a truly ensemble cast who do more than just act, they become the citizens of Bedford Falls. Bailey believes he has reached this low point in his life because he was too busy taking care of everyone else and spending so little time and resources on the betterment of his own situation. Having been convinced by Mr. Potter, the resident curmudgeon (played admirably by Lionel Barrymore) that Bailey was worth more dead than alive, Bailey first attempts to take his own life, then being granted the wish that he'd never been born and ultimately concludes with Bailey standing on a bridge pleading \\"Please! B0007M22TI|2.0|As per the reply from someone from the Celtic Woman production team, to whom I had written to inquire about the lip-synching issue, the audio heard on the DVD is not necessarily the same that corresponds to the images, meaning that it is dubbed and edited over the video. In addition, the images on the DVD are from different shows, and they are all edited together to make it seem as if they were all from the same concert. Here is a copy of the reply they sent me:    \\"Putting together DVDs and albums are very complicated and take many months of work. The DVD is shot over a number of performances, and sometimes the audio may come from a different performance and therefore may not exactly match despite the best technical efforts.\\"    So what this means in plain terms, and I explain it for those who are so emotionally overwhelmed by the concert that they can't see straight, is that the DVD editing team took the sound recording of one concert, and put it over the images of another concert, and combined it so that the sound you are hearing as the singers perform on the DVD is not the actual sound that corresponds to the video. Also, as the email indicates, as you watch the concert progress from one song to the next, you could be seeing different concerts altogether that could've taken place weeks or months apart. All this amounts to a reprehensible misrepresentation by the producers of the DVD, in that it misleads the viewers into thinking they are watching and hearing the actual concert as it happened, rather than a dubbed-over production. No wonder there are so many discrepancies between the voices and the images, as the artists 'sing'. It is unfortunate this is so. The music is beautiful, and there certainly is talent there, this is why I am disappointed (In contrast, I could care less about Ashlee Simpson lip-synching on SNL; low talent=low expectations).    I think the producers of Celtic Woman should have just recorded a single concert, with or without flaws, and presented it as is, keeping the post-production editing to a minimum. This is what makes a live concert special; it doesn't have to be perfect, and anyone with half a brain will understand that. If we want a perfect recording that's what the studio album is for. So the bottom line is, if you're going to buy this DVD you should be aware that this is not a true live concert, in that the music you are hearing does not come from the same concert you are watching.

B00005JO1J|5.0|Suffice it to say that the movie version of \\"Rent\\", nine years after it exploded on Broadway, delivers the goods in late 2005. That in itself is no small feat since its then-topicality brings the story a somewhat tainted 1990's time capsule feel. Credit needs to go to director Chris Columbus, who has the audacity to bring back six of the eight original cast members and does surprisingly little to alter the story structure for the screen. The late Jonathan Larson's energetic, hook-heavy music is what made the show so memorable to me when I saw it during its first year in New York, and the now-familiar score still maintains its searing drive as it flows through the episodic story of almost starving artists living in the squalor of Manhattan's Alphabet City in 1989 with the AIDS epidemic running rampant (currently the neighborhood is going through significant urban renewal). In fact, four of the eight main characters are HIV-positive, and this makes the story resonate as much as the vital music does today.<br /><br />Having the cast return to roles they originated nearly a decade earlier when they epitomized twenties angst is a risky move as the characters would seem to be less compelling inhabited by actors now in their mid-thirties. As it turns out, age is not the issue versus the ability of the actors to generate the excitement they did onstage. Their contributions at minimum are solid and effervescent with some standing out, for example, Anthony Rapp as Mark Cohen, the geeky documentary filmmaker who records the lives of his friends with candor and regret. Jesse L. Martin - he of the dazzling smile and honey-coated baritone - seems genuinely liberated from years of button-down civility on \\"Law and Order\\" to play computer programmer Tom Collins smitten with drag queen Angel portrayed with unbridled pride and poignancy by Wilson Jermaine Heredia. Martin's and Heredia's giddy duet, \\"I'll Cover You\\", is full of such romantic fervor that other more traditional couplings can only aspire to such dizzying heights.<br /><br />Idina Menzel plays the bisexual performance artist Maureen Johnson with real brio though she seems a bit over-the-top even when not performing her supposedly avant-garde work, \\"Over the Moon\\". Despite nailing his passionate solo, \\"One Song Glory\\", Adam Pascal looks somewhat lost in his portrayal of Roger Davis, the tortured singer-songwriter who begrudgingly falls for Mimi Marquez, the borderline junkie/exotic dancer downstairs. With her saucer eyes and flirty demeanor, Rosario Dawson replaces original Daphne Rubin-Vega as Mimi, and she turns out to be an excellent choice, showing off unseen singing and dancing skills within the context of the most screen-savvy performance of the cast. She does an appropriately saucy turn on the showstopper, \\"Out Tonight\\". Rounding out the principal cast are another newcomer, Tracie Thoms, a belter who plays Maureen's lover yuppie lawyer Joanne Jefferson (and consequently wails with immaculate bravura the bridge to the show's most famous song, \\"Seasons of Love\\"), and Taye Diggs, who manages to make the most of the relatively thankless role of Benny Coffin.<br /><br />No matter the variability of the acting, everyone sings with glorious power, a fact made clear at the outset by Columbus, who smartly has them sing \\"Seasons of Love\\" in the manner it was introduced onstage with spotlights on a darkened stage. He also takes cinematic liberties which work in some of the numbers retranslated into the film, such as \\"Light My Candle\\", \\"Tango: Maureen\\" and \\"Take Me As I Am\\". Some like the centerpiece ensemble, \\"La Vie Boheme\\", work almost the same way they did on stage with its sheer exuberance intact. Some scenes don't work as well, for example, \\"What You Own\\" where Roger is literally living out the symbolic lyrics in Santa Fe. With its more naturalistic tone in spite of the numerous breaks into song and dance, the movie reminds me less of Robert Wise's and Jerome Robbins' adaptation of \\"West Side Story\\" than of Milos Forman's take on \\"Hair\\". Be forewarned that those who loved the stage version are the ones who will most be in thrall over the film version. That would include me.Milos Forman's take on \\"Hair\\". Be forewarned that those who loved the stage version are the ones who will most be in thrall over the film version. That would include me.
B000AGTPUA|3.0|Director Robert Zemeckis' films have always used the latest in technology to bring a new way of approaching special effects. The process of animating toons in Who Framed Roger Rabbit without the grain from earlier attempts worked beautifully while Forrest Gump used old archival footage and matched it with recently shot footage and you literally can't tell the difference. Using the book of the same name for inspiration, he brings in a new technology(or let's say a revamped one) that while it does have the visuals, it lacks what should be in a Christmas film: heart. <br /> <br />Hero Boy(I'm literally not making this up, that's how he's credited) is starting to not believe in Christmas. So the titular train stops by picking up other kids who don't and takes them all the way to the North Pole. It's a weird concept personally: rather than let the kids just not believe, it's like \\"alright kid get on and we'll prove to you Santa exists\\". The entire trip takes up the bulk of the film as they go through mini-adventures before reaching the North Pole. <br /> <br />First thing I have to say before I start listing complaints is the visuals: holy crap these look awesome. This film is literally reference quality if you want to test your new TV. The train is quite detailed, the colors, the landscape all has topnotch quality written on it. I'm going to mention the actual characters next because that's where it falters. <br /> <br />One common complaint in reviews was the way the characters looked, especially the eyes. They look rather lifeless and without a soul, as if you were staring into a doll. When the Jolly Fat Man shows up, to me he literally looked like a mannequin. Also mouth movements looked incredibly strange to me. The idea of using \\"performance capture\\" it's the same as motion capture but also capturing the faces is a relatively new technology(the same technique was emplored to bring Gollum to life in the Lord of the Rings trilogy) but the execution is still off. <br/> <br />Another complaint I personally have is the padding of the length. It's literally a 45 minute film stretched out twice the size, you can notice scenes just seem to be put in to expand the length(such as a rather lame hot chocolate song). Also hearing Tom Hanks' recognizable voice coming out of no more than 5(!) characters takes you out of the film a bit. He does an excellent job with Santa though, the only time I couldn't tell it was him. <br /> <br />Now the ever important question: since it's designed to be a holiday film does it work. In a way. Kids will love it. It's got the magic and splendor that Christmas should have although they might find it a bit too suspenseful, especially when the train starts to speed up. Buy it for the kids but as an adult watching it, the flaws will be easily detectable.
6304076517|1.0|Truly one of my favorite movies of all time, marred by an ugly, blurry, muddy, pan/scan VHS transfer.  I'd advise you not to buy this and instead urge the studio to release a DVD in the US.
B000068TPN|5.0|\\"...If you could hear, at every jolt, the blood <br />Come gargling from the froth-corrupted lungs, <br />Obscene as cancer, bitter as the cud <br />Of vile incurable sores on innocent tougnes...\\" <br />              -Wilfred Owen, from his 1917 poem \\"Dulce et Decorum est\\"  <br />I know this is a movie review, but the movie is based on a terrible mistake in history that we still have not learned from, and the historical lesson is more important than the showbusiness. <br /> <br />WE WERE SOLDIERS is a much-needed wake-up-call.  It is a blood-splattering nightmarish accurate depiction of what happens when the United States government goes deaf, blind, and mentally insane all at the same time (i.e. seeing the apparitions of groundless fears).  Aside from the 58,000 American boys just like me who were slaughtered to shreads of dead hamburger meat and the 300,000 who were wounded physically and corrupted mentally, betrayed by the murderous country they fought for, the American military killed three million north Vietnamese who had no imperialistic intentions but instead simply wanted their own country once and for all, free from French occupation.  Ho Chi Minh was not a bad guy at all; he wanted a peaceful, unified, INDEPENDENT Vietnam free from foreign influence and had before the war been willing to embrace any system of government-- anything, even DEMOCRACY-- to accomplish this.  The US did not JUMP on this diplomatic opportunity because they had forgotten or ignored the fact that HO CHI MINH HAD PRAISED THE UNITED STATES' 1776 DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE AND EVEN EMULATED PARTS OF IT IN HIS OWN 1954 VIETNAMESE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE!!  We had the chance to negotiate, to have given him a full copy of our document so that he could have seen what he could do with it further, and war would have been avoided-- sooo easily!  So Ho Chi Minh signed on with the communist party because they were the only ones willing to be tough with the French and to strive for a unified, independent, non-imperialistic Vietnam.  As for the US: Folly? yes. Debacle? certainly. MISUNDERSTANDING? Yes, most of all!. <br />The Vietnamese today, rightly so, call this war \\"THE AMERICAN WAR\\" which is of course a better name for the war because the Americans were the evil agressors in a foreign land of innocent defenders. <br /> <br />A movie, based on reality, well done.  Highly recommended.  Every American should have to go through the pain of watching it, along with the other esteemed movies about the Vietnam, I mean, American War. <br /> <br />Peace and knowledge to all.
B000002699|5.0|Miles always let the music do the talking, so my advice is just listen to this album. Nevertheless, I will bang on about it a bit, just like the others. <br />This is a CD I put on after I come back from the pub, or club at night when I've had a few drinks or whatever. Somehow it just calls out to me \\"Luke... Luke... PLAY ME\\" and I do. It never fails to move me (and sometimes physically). It is a strange, dark brew of textured piano and electric piano riffs and some minimal rythmical work by Williams and Holland, with Miles gliding over it like only he can and John McLaughlin creating great atmosphere with some wonderful guitar work. It is raw, like most Miles Davis stuff, but also very smooth and peaceful - with a kind of dark streak running through the middle. Quite unlike any music you will hear these days, bar perhaps Aphex Twin. <br />When I first got this album I thought it was incredible and powerful and was even quite scared of it for a while - it seemed to possess some kind of quiet voodoo power. There is magic in this music, definitely. But, over the years I have listened to it regularly and it continues to give me warm pleasures. Every listen becomes a rich, rewarding experience. It is a real grower, and calmer than most of Miles' other fusion work. It is a good companion to \\"A Tribute To Jack Johnson\\" (Mainly because of the presence of McLaughlin on guitar), although this album is far less aggressive, and more gentle and mysterious. The album will take you on a pleasant little journey down a bubbling creek, in the middle of the night...

The CG is breath-taking, the snowstorm is astonishing and the train itself is a wonder to behold. The colors are bright when need be, and quiet and deep in the more emotinal scenes. The 3 main child characters are all delightfull, the only exception being a loud, obnoxious, nerdy kid along for the ride who didn't really fit and was not necessary. B00005JO17|4.0|Most of the computer-animated films since Toy Story have been funny enough for adults to enjoy as much as kids, and Chicken Little is no exception.  It's not one of the best, but I liked it better than Madagascar, earlier this year.  Compared to Finding Nemo, Monsters Inc., Shrek, and Ice Age, this one was not quite as consistently funny, though very cute.  However, it added some sci-fi special effects particularly suited to CGI.  There's a piece of the sky - it really turns out to be a piece of something else - that projects an image from one side that's identical to what's behind it, making it effectively invisible, a gimmick I've read about a few years ago in a sci-fi story about nano-technology in Analog magazine.  The CGI effects make this sequence of Chicken Little one of the most amazing of any movie out this year.  Just for laughs, however, Wallace and Grommit and the Curse of the Wear Rabbit, which used traditional stop-motion animation, was a bit funnier.
0316779237|3.0|David Sedaris, playwright and commentator for National Public Radio, gives us six seasonal tales in this slim volume of his short stories.<br /><br />\\"SantaLand Diaries,\\" the recounting of his days working as an elf at Macy's, is far and away the gem of the collection.  Sedaris is hilariously funny as he hits on the universal truths and human patterns of behavior that make Christmas the beloved, harried season that it is.<br /><br />The second story \\"Season's Greetings to Our Friends and Family!\\" begins in an equally funny vein posing as the Christmas letter from hell.  What cheery news does the family who has seen a member murdered and another arrested for the crime write?  Again, hilariously funny, but a rather dark turn at the end left an unseasonably bad taste in my mouth.<br /><br />\\"Dinah, the Christmas Whore\\" continues this walk on the dark side as a young boy follows his sister to her secret life and they bring home a prostitute for Christmas.  He gets a warm and fuzzy feeling knowing they have something no other family does.<br /><br />\\"Front Row Center with Thaddeus Bristol\\" returns to a lighter version of Christmas as Sedaris takes the reader to a variety of elementary school Christmas plays.  Mini actors that only a devoted camcorder-toting parent could love have us laughing even when we know we shouldn't.  Anyone who has ever sat through one of these amateur productions will relate to his wry insights.<br /><br />\\"Based upon a True Story\\" is the most cynical of the selections and hits at the materialistic baseness that lurks in everyone.<br /><br />\\"Christmas Means Giving\\" takes the idea of outdoing your fellow man to the most bizarre of all limits and again, may not be the cheery Christmas feel-good story one is looking for.

B000001FA4|2.0|On the whole, I find this album rather disappointing.  8 out of the 10 songs of the album are not appealing at all.  It may be that the album is too focused on America, if we consider the wording of the song titles: \\"Elvis Presley and America\\", \\"4th of July\\".  Having listened to 7out of 10 albums (not counting the 2 `Best Of'), I still see War as the best U2 album, in spite of it being so noisy. <br />But from this rather mediocre record, two songs stand out.  Though I still have difficulty to fathom what this song is about, The Unforgettable Fire is a catchy track.  But then there is Pride (In the name of love), one of the band's best ever songs, to be put into the same category as New Year's Day (1983) or One (1991).  Pride is a touching tribute to one of the greatest ever Human Rights' fighters, Martin Luther King.  Maybe a little bit of history might help to understand the song better.  Luther King was a pastor in the state of Alabama.  He fought actively for the rights of the oppressed Afro-American community, and in spite of being faced with constant injustice, maintained an approach of peace and non-violence in his efforts to fight racial discrimination.  On April 4th, 1968 he was killed in Memphis by a sniper.  The last part of the song clearly refers to this event: <br />  <br />\\"Early morning, April 4th <br />  Shut rings out, in the Memphis sky\\" <br /> <br />Then, Bono and his band also show a great knowledge of certain little details that make the song more credible as a tribute.  On the tombstone of King was carved the following inscription: \\"Free at last. Free at last. Thank God almighty I'm free at last.\\"  This quote from a religious folk song was often used by King in his speeches.  In turn, Bono and his acolytes make use of these lines:  <br />\\"Free at last, <br />They took your lives <br />They could not take your pride.\\" <br /> <br />U2 have always supported noble causes: fighting against poverty; fair trade; fight against apartheid; human rights.Here, they also pay a tribute to a great person.  Pride is not only a wonderful song but also a fitting homage.  May Martin Luther King rest in peace, and let us hope that his fight will never be forgotten... <br /> <br />P.S: Another song on the album \\"MLK\\", pays tribute to Luther King.
