B0000CCZ34|5.0|Released overseas in 2003, \\"PopArt\\" is a comprehensive retrospective of Pet Shop Boys' UK chart hits. Since 1985, Neil Tennant and Chris Lowe have seen a whooping 35 of their singles hit the Top Twenty; 20 of them have cracked the Top Ten, and 4 have reached Number One. Over the years they have solidified a well-deserved reputation as one of Britain's most respected songwriters and music acts. The first disc, \\"Pop,\\" features the more straightforward perky hits like the Village People cover \\"Go West,\\" the tender ballad \\"Love Comes Quickly,\\" the discocentric \\"Heart,\\" and the love song \\"Miracles,\\" which was recorded exclusively for this album.  Disc 2 is \\"Art,\\" where the songs are more complicated in theme and may require some interpretation. While both discs are pitch-perfect in terms of quality, the \\"Art\\" disc is my personal favorite. This disc has another newly recorded track called \\"Flamboyant,\\" which is an on-point critique on the extravagant life of the celebrity. Other great tracks are \\"So Hard,\\" \\"Rent,\\" \\"Liberation,\\" and the autobiographical \\"Being Boring.\\"  As hits collections go, \\"PopArt\\" is a unique and timeless survey of one of the finest groups around. If you missed out on the duo's last collection, \\"Discography,\\" then you owe it to yourself and your record collection by picking this up. Like all great CDs, it will never leave your stereo.
B0000027RL|5.0|This is without doubt a collection of Pearl Jam's finest work. Classic rockers each and everyone of 'em. Tightly packed, excellently delivered. Vedder's (now) trademark vocal delivery, the screaming and slashing guitars, pulsating bass and thumping drums. <br /> <br />\\"Black\\" ranks up there on the list of power ballads along the lines of Metallica's \\"Fade To Black\\" and Dire Straits \\"You And Your Friend\\" - the feelings the song arouses in you are indescribable. <br /> <br />The album is pure magic. IMHO, the reason I feel Pearl Jam come off better than Nirvana, is that while Nirvana made great music, Pearl Jam - as another reviewer rightly pointed out - looks after the head as well as the heart. I don't understand the logic behind naming them \\"sell outs\\" - just because a band is successful doesn't automatically make them \\"mainstream\\". Just because you are radio friendly doesn't automatically make you a \\"sell out\\". Reasoning of this kind is snobbery - pure and simple. <br /> <br />I give this album a 5 stars - it's right up there with my 'Dark Side of the Moon' and The Doors debut album. <br /> <br />Get this one - you will fall in love with it like millions around the world have :-)

B000AADYRQ|4.0|With Plans, DCFC venture into more adult territory, offering up 11 new rock-pop gems. A lot of people are quick to say that after signing with Atlantic, the band's sound has changed to accommodate the more 'radio friendly' listeners. I have to disagree! All the quality, classic DCFC elements are still here. Yes, their sound is more polished, a lot less lo-fi, and lyrically more direct...but they've still managed to produce an excellent album.  When I first listened to it I was pretty lukewarm about it. It's one of those that really grows on you after you pay closer attention. It wasn't what I was expecting; however, after being more patient I was pleasantly surprised.<br /><br />The songwriting is really delicate at times, almost to the point of being mushy, but it's endearing and not a put off like you'd think.  If your wary of investing in the 'new' DCFC at least check out \\"What Sarah Said\\", \\"Brothers on a hotel bed\\", \\"Crooked Teeth\\".<br /><br />Overall, I'd definitely recommend this and say it's more than worth the 15 or however many dollars.  Really beautiful melodies, stand-out drumming and Ben Gibbard's signature lyrical styling make this one of the best releases of 2005.
B00005JKLZ|4.0|I saw the 1960 film version of \\"The Time Machine\\" in 1968, when it was shown on network television (I've seen it again since then). Just a few years later, I found a copy of the book and read it, enjoying it very much. First, lets get one thing out of the way. Neither movie version of \\"The Time Machine\\" has been absolutely faithful to the original novel written in 1895. Both departed from their literary source in ways which seemed appropriate for the times in which they were made. Having made that point, this, the 2002 version stands as a very good movie which can stand on its own merits, even if one has never read the novel.<br /><br />One feature I liked about this movie is that it does answer some questions which the book left unanswered (or even, unasked). The first of these is why the inventor is interested in time travel in the first place. It might be sufficient to give simple curiosity as a reason, but I believe the reason given in the film is more compelling. I do disagree with one point which the movie seems to imply, the premise that the past cannot be changed. Events happen the way they do not because of fate, but because people are either in the wrong place at the wrong time, or because they (or someone else) makes a decision one way instead of another. As one example, had the captain of the Titanic given orders to reduce speed at night, or adopted a slightly different course, the tragedy which befell his ship might well have been averted. In \\"The Time Machine\\", the inventor is driven to build the machine because he wants to change an event in his own recent past. He is then driven to journey into the distant future in hopes of discovering why he cannot change the past.<br /><br />This version does give affectionate nods both to the book and the 1960 version of the film. Writing in 1895, Wells describes the machine as having quartz rods, one of which was improperly made, and had to be made again. In this film version, we actually see numerous crystalline rods arranged in two rotating sections so as to form parts of a sphere. When energized, they create a field which forms a complete, spherical bubble around the machine, effectively \\"insulating\\" it from the time stream. The interesting thing here is that quartz crystals form the timekeeping element in the majority of watches and clocks sold today, although they were not invented until the 1960's. Was this just a lucky guess on H.G. Wells part?<br /><br />One of the actors from the 1960 version has a cameo role in this film, and one sequence, in which the machine is moving forward through time while the inventor watches fashions change in a dress shop across the street has been retained.<br /><br />Another question which the book does not answer is \\"Why did the time traveller never return after his last voyage\\" (he did make a brief return to have dinner with his friends, and tell them of his adventures). It is left up to the reader to imagine what could have happened. In this film, we are shown what happens, and it is a satisfactory resolution, given his reason for building the machine.<br /><br />Some of the themes of the book are explored a bit more deeply, such as the social rift between the laborers and the social elite, which was apparant even in Wells day. The film shows the result of these social classes actually becoming separate species through millenia of enforced separation.<br /><br />The movie does have some flaws, which have been noted by other reviewers. It is difficult to imagine any artifacts from the 20th century lasting 800,000 years, yet they have a few in the far distant future. I can imagine a piece of stainless steel, such as a knife lasting that long, but not easily can I see a computer so durable, yet there is one in the film. In spite of this, I did like the character played by Orlando Jones, the \\"ghost\\" in the computer, someone not in the book, nor anything Wells would have likely even thought of, yet an interesting and worthwhile addition.<br /><br />Admittedly, the Moon breaking up in the 21st century as a result of nuclear explosions is also inconsistent with what we know of impact crater physics, which are MUCH more powerful than current nuclear weapons.<br /><br />I do take exception with the \\"goofs\\" list on this films description, in which it is claimed that the bicycle-type wheels on the steam carriage are not correct for the time (1895-1900). The fact is, much of early automobile technology was borrowed directly from the bicycle industry, and the earliest Stanley, Locomobile, White and other steam cars, as well as the earliest Fords, Oldsmobiles, Haynes, (gasoline cars) ALL had bicycle type wheels, only adopting wooden wheels later. The car in the film appears to be a Locomobile (or a replica), and is correctly shown with bicycle type wheels. However, the soundtrack does have the wrong engine sound dubbed in, a sputtering gasoline engine noise audible as it is driven away. Rudyard Kipling owned a Locomobile, and described it as \\"noiseless\\". The hissing steam sounds and visible steam clouds do seem correct.<br /><br />However, these are small points to pick on. Taken as a whole, the film is enjoyable and exciting. I thought all the actors gave fine performances, and most of the special effects were excellent. I'm pleased to have added this to my permanent collection.on breaking up in the 21st century as a result of nuclear explosions is also inconsistent with what we know of impact crater physics, which are MUCH more powerful than current nuclear weapons.  <br />I do take exception with the \\"goofs\\" list on this films description, in which it is claimed that the bicycle-type wheels on the steam carriage are not correct for the time (1895-1900). The fact is, much of early automobile technology was borrowed directly from the bicycle industry, and the earliest Stanley, Locomobile, White and other steam cars, as well as the earliest Fords, Oldsmobiles, Haynes, (gasoline cars) ALL had bicycle type wheels, only adopting wooden wheels later. The car in the film appears to be a Locomobile (or a replica), and is correctly shown with bicycle type wheels. However, the soundtrack does have the wrong engine sound dubbed in, a sputtering gasoline engine noise audible as it is driven away. Rudyard Kipling owned a Locomobile, and described it as \\"noiseless\\". The hissing steam sounds and visible steam clouds do seem correct. <br />However, these are small points to pick on. Taken as a whole, the film is enjoyable and exciting. I thought all the actors gave fine performances, and most of the special effects were excellent. I'm pleased to have added this to my permanent collection.

B000AP04FG|4.0|Okay, so this is not an epic movie. It's not even a serious movie, but it is so much fun to watch!<br /><br />Mr. And Mrs. Smith live such very ho-hum lives. They are bored with each other to the point that they go to a marriage counselor. That's where the movie opens. Our characters are uptight and find each other intensely boring. At home they are polite to each other and live a quiet life in a beautiful home. Can this marriage be saved. You bet it can.<br /><br />Though they masquerade as a computer engineer and an architect, they are so much more. Their offices are fronts for their real activities - they each belong to a clandestine organization that neither one knows about. The marriage is just a front, but both are unaware of the other's activities. I won't say more about the plot, wouldn't want to ruin it for anyone.<br /><br />The movie takes off from quiet and boring to intense and loaded with espionage and shootouts that are amazingly well done, making it easier for you to suspend belief. Sprinkled in are some truly hilarious scenes with supporting characters that will leave you laughing out loud.<br /><br />This movie was a lot of fun. I highly recommend it.
